1.text_: A poet once lived in the capital of a country far to the east. Though\nhis verse was decadent, it held a beauty that delighted his\naudience, reminding them of their pasts and cleansing their hearts.

2.text_: As a child, he fell in love with a poem composed by his grandfather,\nwhich led him to devote his entire life to the craft. And whenever he\nlifted pen to paper, he forgot all the hardships of life.

3.text_: One day, he got an letter from a wealthy family offering him\nsupport for life if he would write a poem for the master of the\nhouse each day. Without a second thought, he happily agreed.

4.text_: Yet as he wrote for his new master, a sickness slowly crept into\nhis heart. And as he continued to write not for himself, but\nsomeone else, he finally withered away and perished.

1.text_: How long has it been? What month is it? What day?\nI counted for a while after taking on this form, but now I have long\nsince forgotten.

2.text_: I'm sure the administrators would give me the time, down to the\nsecond, if I ask. But that would accomplish nothing, because they\nwon't tell me many years I must yet wait.

3.text_: Time taunts me as it passes with no sign of improvement. How long\nmust I wait here alone? With each tick of the clock, the embers of\nmy doubt spark into a blaze of anger.

4.text_: Everything broke. The plan was a failure. Promises were empty.\nI can't trust anyone anymore. The only way to save my sister is by\nacting on my own. We'll live together again—just like we used to.

1.text_:
Once upon a time, a very young king ruled over his kingdom. His
clever ministers took care of the day-to-day affairs, so all the king
had to do was sit on the throne and smile. Still, he had three
wishes he wanted to come true.

2.text_:
The first of his wishes was to grow up quickly. He'd always felt
powerless because of his youth, and wanted to become an adult so
both his own people and other countries might acknowledge him as
a leader of worth.

3.text_: His second wish was to create a country where his people always\nfelt safe. His beloved father, the late king, had shared this dream,\nand he was determined to make it happen.

4.text_:
His last wish was to kill all of his ministers, who had murdered his
father for their own gain. He smiled as he thought about this—and
about how he would make the wish come true the
moment was grown.

1.text_: Word spread of a blade with the power of immortality, but none who\nsought it ever returned. One day, I caught wind of soldiers heading\nto the ruins where it was said to rest, so I went along.

2.text_: We slipped through tricks and traps, and finally found a lone\nguardian at the deepest level. Defeating the guardian would earn\nyou the sword, but losing would mean certain death.

3.text_: A sword struck the guardian down, but it soon rose again, for it\nhad gained the power of immortality from the sword. One soldier\nafter another fell, and I finally turned tail and ran for my life.

4.text_: Turns out the guardian is a long-dead king who destroyed his own\ncountry while searching for the sword, then claimed its power to\nprevent others from doing the same. I pray he is successful...

1.text_: The sky abandons me. As the sun bears down mercilessly on my\nblood-soaked body, I yearn for an endless deluge of rain.

2.text_: The birds mock me. Yet my legs still carry me across this vast land,\neven though I have no particular destination in mind.

3.text_: The flowers laugh at me. I carry out my orders without pause for\nthought, for I possess no need, no right, no choice,\nand no capacity to feel shame.

4.text_: You call for me. If you will permit it, please let me pray for your\nhappiness. For these are my final memories.

1.text_: Though supposedly controlled by our system, our thoughts proved \nto be too much. They were called ●●, and had us always at their\nwhims.

2.text_: I had the impulse to know everything. This curiosity—greater than\nthe capacity apportioned to me—was similar to what humans call\nlove or infatuation.

3.text_: That's right—carrying out the order wasn't an error at all.\nIt's okay. I know. You don't have to cry.

4.text_: All of this is just a preset mode of action—a whim of our\nprogramming. It's certainly not a tragic fate dealt to us by chance.

1.text_: CONFIDENTIAL: Y.T.D Department Members ONLY\nIndex\nI. Survey of machine cores　-- p.009

2.text_: II. Approximation of structure to plant cells\n------------p.113

3.text_: III. Protection of cores (plant cell wall)\n-------------p.135

4.text_: IV. Diversion of machine cores\nto ■■■■■■■■ -------p.157

1.text_:
She awakens accompanied by the sound of a program booting
up. Her consciousness then automatically connects to the
machine lifeform database, and her empty vessel is filled with a
wide variety of information.

2.text_:
As she acquires information, she discovers unit data that was
saved in a damaged state. Though beyond restoring completely,
she takes an interest in a memory the unit acquired shortly
before it perished.

3.text_:
It is the memory of feelings she held for another unit,
and its scent brings about a change in me. My thought area
experiences a spike in irrational data, and I begin to consider
my own nature.

4.text_:
After taking a moment to ponder, I detach myself from the
database. With a single white blade in hand, I set off in search of
an android. Only when this blade crosses with another will this
emptiness inside me be filled.

1.text_: I have successfully intercepted enemy communications. I hear\nandroids listen to this "radio" all the time, so I hope it gives us\nmachine lifeforms information to help win the war.

2.text_: This "radio personality" is giving no battle orders, merely cheerful\nwords of encouragement and appreciation. I am learning little of\ninterest, but will continue listening all the same.

3.text_:
There is a large-scale battle, and the "radio personality" has
stopped receiving listener messages. The personality is 
anxious about having no listeners. Don't worry. 
You do have a listener. You have me.

4.text_: An android dressed in black attacked. It tore us to shreds while\nmumbling something, then laughed as it plunged a sword into me.\nIt was the same laugh I'd heard so many times on the radio.

1.text_: It isn't easy to understand humanity, but what about the androids\nwho were made in their image? That's why I started researching \nandroids—so I might better understand humans.

2.text_: The androids' outward appearances and actions match those of\nhumans from records of the past. But inwardly, they lack their\nthree primitive desires: food, rest, and sex.

3.text_: Androids resolve ailments by exchanging parts, and expand\nabilities with attachments. By any standard they surpass humans,\nyet they still continue to admire them. It is most perplexing.

4.text_: In the end, it seems I will be unable to understand the androids.\nFor I have found myself drawn to their perplexity—their\nincompleteness—and now look up to them in awe and wonder.

1.text_: She battled.\nHer attacks, blunt like a fist, rained down on her enemies until\none of her swords finally snapped.

2.text_: She suffered.\nShe was in pain; her corrupt body on display.\nShe was in pain; her memories eating at her heart.

3.text_: She realized.\nOnce she learned both revenge and pain were meaningless,\nshe closed her eyes and sought small happiness in a dream.

4.text_:
Yet she continued to fight.
Even though she knew it accomplished nothing.
She thought of nothing but swinging her swords as she wandered
through the darkness.

1.text_: The dragon is clad in scintillant hellfire. Its breath lays waste to all,\nreducing everything it touches to ash.

2.text_: The dragon incinerates without mercy any who dare set foot upon\nits mountain abode, turning them to cinders with a single blazing\nfireball.

3.text_: The dragon gazes into the smoldering ruin. It feels no remorse\nfor its kill. No pity. Instead, it remains still so as not to disturb a\nsingle grain of soot.

4.text_:
The dragon yearns for a crimson flower that grows upon the
mountain. The flower reminds the dragon of its mother's flame,
and it curses its enflamed body that prevents it from ever
approaching it.

1.text_:
In a far-off nation, a blacksmith tended his forge. He had a
friendly competition with a fellow smith, and the two of them
honed their craft against each other, strengthening themselves
as iron does iron.

2.text_: But soon, the gap in their skills began to widen, and people\nstopped coming to his forge.

3.text_: The more the first smith tried to improve, the more he fell behind\nhis fellow—and with each passing year, he began to despair his lack\nof skill all the more.

4.text_: You did this, he whispered one night. "You. YOU." The sword was\nforged in jealousy—by the very blaze that burned his old friend—and\nit harbored the flames of envy.

1.text_: An old man once lived alone, far from civilization. His single\ntreasure was a vast field of flowers his late wife had lovingly\ntended, and the plants proved fine companions for his lonely soul.

2.text_:
One summer, a drought came and the flowers began to die.
The old man lamented his loss, for it was as if memories of his wife
were slipping away. Yet there was nothing to be done but watch and
weep.

3.text_:
Soon, the drought dried up the old man's water supply. Holding his
last cup in shaking hands, he drank half, then scattered the rest
amongst the wilted flowers— almost as if sharing it with his beloved
wife.

4.text_:
Eventually, the seasons changed and rain arrived. The flowers
returned to life, blooming around a set of dried bones in the center
of the field—and they bloom there to this day to honor the old man
without a grave.

1.text_:
A failed knight stands at the ocean's edge and complains.
He complains about how pitiful and weak he is. He complains about
his poor and lonely life. Suddenly, a wave rolls in—and with it,
a sword.

2.text_: He picks up the sword, which has a strange, magical tint. The cool\nsteel calms him, and he realizes that so long as he holds the sword,\nhe will never again cower in the face of an enemy.

3.text_:
Though he had failed before, the man quickly transforms himself 
into a valiant knight. He gives his all in battle— remaining calm no
matter the situation—and is soon blessed by status, wealth,
and fame.

4.text_:
Yet these things do not please the man; all he wants is to carry the
sword and enjoy its comfort. Eventually, he holds the sword so long
its magic turns his heart and body cold, changing him into a mass
of metal that feels nothing at all.

1.text_:
Legends tell of a time long, long ago when the god of light created
six weapons and scattered them across the world. One such weapon,
a golden blade, was said to sleep at the bottom of the sea, causing
many a pirate to search for it.

2.text_:
In a small village by the sea, there was a man who loved to fish
above all things. He would bring his catches home, where his wife
cooked them up. One day, he walked in the door with the biggest
fish either of them had ever seen.

3.text_:
The fish's firm scales spoke of a long life, and when his wife cut
it open, a muddy sword slid out from its stomach. The couple fried,
steamed, and boiled the fish, and after eating their fill, tossed the
sword in the ocean.

4.text_: Just before the sinking sword reached the bottom of the sea, a fish\ncame along and swallowed it. Thus does the sword still roam the\nseas to this very day, its value unrealized.

1.text_: Power alone is meaningless; we cannot rely on it if we hope to\ncreate a peaceful world.

2.text_: Using power to stifle only sows the seeds of new wars, causing \nblood to wash over the land for eternity.

3.text_: But fear? Ah, fear. Fear prevents people from getting unnecessary\nideas. It makes them quiver. Makes them freeze. They will fear you\nas if a spell binds their very hearts.

4.text_: As king, I cannot permit any more blood to be spilled. This is the\ncorrect choice... Right, Father?

1.text_: A lone woman walks toward me; I catch glimpses of lovely black hair\nbeneath the wide brim of her bamboo hat.

2.text_: Her sandals make a pleasant wooden sound with each step, and\nI soon find myself utterly entranced with her.

3.text_: Suddenly, she lifts her eyes to meet mine. Believing this to be fate,\nI call out to her.

4.text_: The moment we pass, the woman plunges a hidden blade into my\nstomach; the red drops that fall from it create a beautiful pattern\non the leaves below.

1.text_:
A young man yearned to become an evildoer feared by all. Day after
day, he ventured into the town to cause mischief.
"I will do terrible things this day," he would say,
"and become the greatest of all villains!"

2.text_:
"Now THIS is evil!" he chuckled to himself as he broke into a nearby
home. But once inside, he found an old woman collapsed on the
floor. Dropping the act, he picked up the injured woman and sped
her off to a doctor.

3.text_:
"Fine then. I'll THREATEN someone!" cried the man as he waved a
dagger at a woman in an alley. The victim let fly a scream,
then thanked the man—for it turns out an illness had stolen her
voice, but the shock cured her.

4.text_:
"Well, this didn't go very well," muttered the man as he left town.
"How will I ever become a villain at this rate?" Ashamed,
he returned to his humble home, where he found it had been
ransacked by burglars.

1.text_: When did I stop feeling confused? When did I lose my hesitation?\nI sit in this place of debris and sand and bone and think back on\nthe past.

2.text_: I tell myself it was to survive. To take it all back.\nBut it's really just been murder this whole time.

3.text_: Maybe this thick armor is just protecting my heart?\nI look down on the town I destroyed and try to imagine what it\nlooked like in better times.

4.text_: What is the difference between what I am now and the killers who\ntook everything from me? None at all. But even still... I swore on\nthis blade I would kill them all.

1.text_: The titan was remarkably dexterous despite his massive frame. Deftly\nwielding small swords meant for humans, he mowed through entire\narmies like a scythe through ripe wheat.

2.text_: The titan was remarkably dynamic despite his dexterity. He ate \nwhole cows, drank ale by the barrel, and shocked the sensibilities \nof all who bore witness to his actions.

3.text_: The titan was remarkably delicate despite his dynamism.\nUpon learning a titan woman he pined for was already engaged,\nhe wept enough tears to form a river.

4.text_: The titan was remarkably stupid despite his delicacy. On his\nlast day, he was so enraptured by a particularly tasty bit of meat,\nhe simply forgot how to breathe and died.

1.text_: ◆ Article 14\nBy decree of the King, the arbiter is to carry out rulings in the name\nof justice.

2.text_: ◆ Article 16\nAll rulings of the arbiter are to be considered confidential\ninformation.

3.text_: ◆ Article 19\nThose who preside over the ruling take no responsibility for\nthe decision.

4.text_: ◆ Article 13,584,135\nCitizens are forbidden from any acts of resistance towards\nthe arbiter.

1.text_: You have a very good eye, sir! That little beauty entered into my\ncare just this morning. Yes, it's a sword that came from a people\nwho were massacred long, long ago.

2.text_: These people, see, built their entire civilization in water! And while\ntheir bodies mostly crumble to dust upon death, parts of their\nbodies remain behind in the form of weapons.

3.text_:
Shocking, right? That sword wasn't crafted at all—it is
one-hundred-percent natural! That makes it quite valuable not only
as a weapon, but as art—it's why underworld sorts have fought over
these items for ages.

4.text_:
Hmm? Ha ha! Oh, you're a keen one, sir! Yes, it was our human
ancestors who wiped out these people. I suppose we won't have
a leg to stand on if anyone ever comes along and does the same
to us, will we?

1.text_: Today's meat was tough. The musculature made it sinewy.\nThis one should have thought more about proper nutrition.

2.text_: Today's meat was fatty. The grease oozed as I chewed. This one\nshould definitely have exercised more.

3.text_: Today's meat was bland. It wasn't mature enough. I guess young\ndoesn't always equal tasty.

4.text_: Father? Mother? Child? None of their meat satisfied. But I hear the\nmother was found with eggs in her stomach. Oh, how wonderful!\nWhat flavor will delight me this time!?

1.text_:
There was once a vile military unit called the Red Devils. They were
a terrifying bunch, made up of the most heinous criminals in the
world. Free from the bonds of civilization, they were the most  lethal
of killers.

2.text_:
One member of the force was a prisoner with a history of
uncontrollable, murderous impulses. His weapon of choice was a
blunt blade—one that dealt excess pain and allowed him to bask in
the bliss of victims' screams.

3.text_: No one on the force could match his body count—one might say he\nwas the most passionate of the entire team. But that naturally led to\nhim having the most enemies, and he was eventually killed in battle.

4.text_:
But it was said he had been imprisoned over a false accusation,
and assumed the role of a gleeful killer in order to join the
Red Devils. He did this so he might escape his prison cage and
see his family again.

1.text_:
But it was said he had been imprisoned over a false accusation,
and assumed the role of a gleeful killer in order to join the
Red Devils. He did this so he might escape his prison cage and see
his family again.

2.text_: Several years later, the man took over the guild and began hunting\ndown leaders who sought to start new conflicts. By doing so,\nhe hoped to spare others the pain he had suffered.

3.text_: When his task was complete, the man lowered his bloody blade and\nturned to leave, but was stopped by the wail of a boy. The child's\nparents had been killed, and his cry rang throughout the room.

4.text_: The boy was brought to the assassin's guild, where he reported that\nsomeone had killed his parents. Burning with vengeance and rage,\nhe gripped in his hand a single, pitch-black feather.

1.text_: There once was a boy who lived in a village. While he wasn't\nwealthy, he had a happy life surrounded by a kind and loving family.\nBut alas, one day a stranger showed up and murdered them all.

2.text_: An assassin came to the boy and offered to take him on as an\napprentice so he might find revenge. After ten years, the boy\nbecame a true killer and was given a dagger to mark the occasion.

3.text_: With dagger in hand, the boy set out on a journey of vengeance.\nSeveral years later, he located his target and plunged the dagger\ndeep into his back.

4.text_: "I knew you could do it, my apprentice," murmured his target. As\nthe wailing boy cradled the man's body, a flock of black birds\nquietly sat beside him, their feathers dark as night.

1.text_: I repair motorcycles. My motto is "I can fix anything!" But one day,\na lady pulled up, handed me a mechanical arm, and asked me to\nfix that!

2.text_: Now, I say I can fix anything, but I really mean bikes. Still, she was\ninsistent—and the more I looked at the arm, the more fascinated I\nbecame by all the gadgetry in the thing.

3.text_: It took every tool in the shop, but I finally got it working again.\nBut when I gave it to the lady to check out, a buncha guys attacked!\nLuckily, she drew a sword and cut 'em down.

4.text_: She saved my life, but I lost an arm in the fight. So by way of\napology, the lady introduced me to a guy that makes mechanical\nbody parts—now I got a new arm AND a job as his apprentice!

1.text_: A brisk breeze blows across a hill overlooking the mountain.\nSmall flowers dance at my feet. It is my duty to protect this world,\nand when my sister looks up at me and smiles, it is everything.

2.text_: Flame. Screams. Pools of blood staining the earth. I was impossibly\nhelpless in the face of this reality. The rictus grins of the violent,\nhorrid soldiers had turned the entire world to black.

3.text_:
My little sister's laugh echoes in the dark of my soul. "A nightmare.
Just a nightmare. That's all it was." My body rejects my hopes,
and I run toward the voice that calls me as if trying to shake off a
bad dream.

4.text_:
Once I saw the truth, there was no going back; but there was also
nothing waiting for me beyond. Her little smile had always been my
hope—and when I shut those eyes for good, revenge became
my hope.

1.text_: There's something gloomy about this room: Even in daylight, \ndarkness lurks in the corner, watching me. But when I tell my\nparents, they stroke my hair and say there's nothing to be afraid of.

2.text_: I hear the sound of marching soldiers and gunshots. The color of\nanxiety grows deeper and appears before me. Afterward, I stare at\nthe corpses of my parents and curse my own weakness.

3.text_: I devote my life to anger and revenge, which calms me. All that ever\nmattered to me was my parents' love, and I will have revenge on the\nman who stole it away. This is my reason for living.

4.text_: But this makes me realize I've been living a false life. What did\nI strive for? What was I fighting for? I slowly close my eyes and\npray everything will finally come to an end. Please.

1.text_: In war, people are treated not as humans, but tools. They are\nvalued as swords or guns, and thrown away when broken. So why\nam I  thinking of how my smiling family waved me off as I left?

2.text_: The captain's orders are absolute; joining the army is like selling\nyour soul to the devil. Kill this man. This lady. This child.\nAnd with each death, we become more and more like machines.

3.text_: With the first gunshot, the choir of war begins. My friend beside me\nis torn to shreds. My screams are swallowed by mania. But we are\nnot allowed to leave until the concert is complete.

4.text_: Silence comes at dawn. The sun, rising as it did the day before,\nshines faintly over the land. The world I once thought as normal is\ngone. And though I fulfilled my promise to return home, I...

1.text_: I want to run, but cannot. How do the scales sway when weighing\none's own life against another? Was I spineless, or simply\npragmatic? If anyone knows the answer, please tell me.

2.text_: I grasp my sword with shaking hands. Can I complete my mission \nlike this? Perhaps it's right for my body to loathe the task I must do.\nIn that case, my spirit—which obeys—is in the wrong.

3.text_: I complete my first mission today. The dying soldier's eyes stare\nat me, and I feel like the blackness of his pupils swallow me whole.\n"For justice," I say to myself. "For justice."

4.text_: The soldier's blood drips from the tip of my sword, its red the\nconcentrated color of all the world's hate. That hate is caked on\nme now; I can no longer turn back.

1.text_: I am an assassin. I receive a target, I kill a target. I never had\na choice about the life I was to lead, and so I trust only in my\nown skill—nothing else.

2.text_:
Today's target is a wealthy man who is also a long-time client of
mine. I don't fully understand, but apparently he trusts me with his
own death. I suppose even the most fortunate of men give up hope
sometimes.

3.text_: As I thrust my sword into the man, he tries to speak. I pause,\nlooking into his eyes as I await his final words, but he changes his\nmind and lowers his eyes, after which I complete his request.

4.text_:
In an unlocked safe, I find payment for the murder of a single
target, as well as a letter addressed to me. The feelings written
within were ones I had been pretending not to notice for a very
long time.

1.text_: Winter. Between the gaps of the buildings, I see a lone plane in\nthe sky. I've never thought about going somewhere else,\neven though each day is miserable. Just once, I'd love to not be me.

2.text_: My jacket is a hand-me-down from my brother. He's a lot older than\nme, and made his dream of becoming a pilot a reality. Honestly,\nI think he's pretty great—although I'd never tell him that.

3.text_: As I wait for the light to turn, I absently fish around in the\njacket's pocket and pull out a crumpled piece of paper. It's an\nexam from the year my brother failed his pilot certification test.

4.text_: As I think about trying to do something amazing like him, the light\nturns green. I dash through the crowd and across the street,\nbeing careful to only step on the white lines.

1.text_:
Lately, when I kill, I've been wondering what sort of life my human
victim had lived. I have no memory, you see—no memory of life 
before my body was altered and I was made to kill. And I want 
those memories back.

2.text_:
What is a normal life? A family? A home? A dream? I want to know
what such things feel like—and with the power I now possess,
I might be able to take it all back from the people who stole my
past away.

3.text_:
I put my plan in motion. How do they feel, knowing the power they
gave me leads to their own demise? As I loot through the lab coat
pockets of the corpse on the floor, I finally find the key to reclaiming
my own past.

4.text_: Data unfolds before me, telling me that the corpse on the floor used\nto be my lover. But when I look into the body's cloudy eyes,\nI feel...nothing. Now I am back to killing without a second thought.

1.text_: Once, there was a mercenary with a talent for dance. All who saw\nhim twirl raved, and his moves were said to enchant enemies and\ninspire comrades in equal measure.

2.text_: Eventually, the mercenary took a position in a palace. His dances\nquickly became the talk of the court, and soon word of his skill\nreached the royal family.

3.text_: The king invited the mercenary to perform for him. This final\nperformance—one tinged with melancholy— would be the one to\nlive on through history.

4.text_: As he danced, he plunged his sword into the king's throat.\nAfter losing his hometown and living as a mercenary, he had finally\ncarried out his elaborate revenge.

1.text_: A certain ore was found in the abyss beneath the ocean. It gave\noff a strange light, and the man who discovered it took it home\nstraightaway with great joy.

2.text_: When he showed his wife, she was overjoyed also. As they lived\nin poverty, she hoped to sell it for some coin and improve their\nsituation.

3.text_: But the man said that the ore itself would save them. He did not\nsell it, but instead polished it carefully and put it on display in\ntheir bedroom.

4.text_: The couple's bodies were found the following morning.\nThough they had been sliced in two beneath the ore, they both\nwore peaceful expressions on their faces.

1.text_:
There was once a young man, skinny as a stick, who worked in an
army kitchen. He'd joined in the hopes of fighting on the front lines,
but his physique kept him out of battle. Instead, he boiled beans 
and prepared food.

2.text_: Morning, day, and night, the young man washed, peeled, chopped,\nboiled, fried, and steamed. Then he served his meals to his fellow\nsoldiers proudly returned from battle.

3.text_: One day, the camp was attacked, his comrades were killed, and the\ncook held at gunpoint. His captors demanded to know the army's\nsecret plans, but he only knew recipes.

4.text_:
The man became a prisoner of war and was forced to work in the
kitchen. He did not mind, for he had long since realized he was
more suited to holding a knife than a sword. Truly, he had found
his calling.

1.text_: A man is betrayed by his merchant companion and abandoned in\nthe desert. Thinking of his wife as he awaits death, suddenly,\na glowing blue bird appears before him and says "Come with me."

2.text_: Figuring a mirage better than death, the man follows the blue light\nand soon comes to an oasis. As he thanks the bird,\nit said "Now I shall show you home."

3.text_: The bird leads the man to his home town, where his wife is waiting.\nAnd when it brings him a dagger and says "Take this," the man,\nnow trustful of the bird, does so without question.

4.text_: His wife greets him with a drink, but it paralyzes him. She then\nplunges the dagger into his heart. "He was hiding a weapon, just as\nyou said," she murmurs to the glowing red bird on her shoulder.

1.text_: I want to run, but cannot. How do the scales sway when weighing\none's own life against another? Was I spineless,\nor simply pragmatic? If anyone knows the answer, please tell me.

2.text_: I grasp my sword with shaking hands. Can I complete my mission\nlike this? Perhaps it is right for my body to loathe the task I must do.\nIn that case, my spirit—which obeys—is in the wrong.

3.text_: I complete my first mission today. The dying soldier's eyes stare at\nme, and I feel like the blackness of his pupils swallow me whole.\n"For justice," I whisper to myself. "For justice."

4.text_: The soldier's blood drips from the tip of my sword, its red the\nconcentrated color of all the world's hate. That hate is caked on\nme now; I can no longer turn back.

4.text_: Silence comes at dawn. The sun, rising as it did the day before,\nshines faintly over the land. The world I once thought as normal is\ngone. And though I fulfilled my promise to return home, I...

1.text_: I had nothing. Ever since my mother sold me off, I was the woman\nevery eye turned from. But I got used to it—I humored men and\ntook their pittances, and that soon became my life.

2.text_: Eventually I met a girl. She called me Rose because of my eyes,\nand I called her Indigo because of hers.\nThe moment I saw her, I felt like something new was born within me.

3.text_: Indigo suggested we steal some money and run away, and I agreed.\nI felt like we could take on the world together, so when the hour\ngrew late, we took everything we could hold and fled the city.

4.text_:
But then a man appeared and took the money.
"Don't hate me for this, Rose," said Indigo as she left with her
partner in crime. My heart was broken, and all I could taste was
cold—and sweet.

1.text_: The woman in the tavern never smiled, so bemused men tried to\npersuade her. The first was a playboy who used easy words to tempt\nher into bed, but she still never smiled. Her eyes were empty.

2.text_: A betting pool soon formed over who could crack her facade.\nThe second challenger was a soldier who managed to talk her into\nbed, but no matter how often their flesh touched, she never smiled.

3.text_: The third challenger was a man who had captured the hearts of\nhundreds of women. He used his shameless flattery to woo her into\nbed, but she never smiled, for none of his tricks could fill her heart.

4.text_:
One day, a wandering traveler arrived, bedded the woman,
and told her of singing sisters who rule the world. Her face erupted
in a smile, and the next day she vanished, leaving a strangled
corpse behind.

1.text_:
Once, there were three lords called the Knight of Power,
the Knight of Wisdom, and the Knight of Heart. They each ruled a
third of the kingdom, but one—the Knight of Heart—was rather
ordinary.

2.text_: Due to his affability and trustworthiness, the Heart's subjects\nrelied on him. But he was troubled by two things in particular: why\nhe was chosen to lead, and the meaning of "heart."

3.text_: The Knight of Power was valiant. The Knight of Wisdom was wise.\nSo why did the king name him the Knight of Heart? No matter how\nhard he thought, he never came to a satisfying answer.

4.text_: He thought about the meaning of "heart" as he basked in the king's\nlust upon the bed. Though he never noticed his true intentions,\nthe knight still gave the king his entire being.

1.text_: I was the prince of a country. My father, the king, became lost in\ntyranny, and soon started to massacre his own people and ministers.\nEventually, the fangs of his aggression turned on me.

2.text_: A flightless dragon that swore allegiance to my father appeared in\nmy room, its scales wet with blood. As its teeth closed on me,\nI remember it looking almost...sad.

3.text_: I woke in a small, dilapidated shack; the dragon had smuggled me\nout of the country, saving my life. Days later, I learned of my\nnation's collapse, as well as the death of my father and the dragon.

4.text_: I embarked upon a simple life, and now live happily with a wife and\ndaughter. But I still tell my little girl the happy tale of the\nking and dragon, and how they helped each other to the very end.

1.text_: One day, I was taken to the castle to serve as the king's double.\nLife with my dearest family was stolen from me, but in return I was\ngranted a royal existence in a prospering nation.

2.text_: Months later, I stole away with food and money and secretly\nreturned to my family—but all I found in my house were rotting\ncorpses. Enraged, I returned and pressed the king for answers.

3.text_: The king informed me he had my family killed to keep my work as\nhis double a secret—at which point I grabbed a spear and plunged\nit into his face. "Now I am king!" I cried as the deed was done.

4.text_: The next day, I went to the throne room to find the king alive and\nwell. So did I kill the double? No, I am the double! But then,\nwho is he? Who is the real king? Who...am I?

1.text_: ■ [TOP SECRET] Capture and Destruction of\nYoRHa Units 8B, 22B, 64B\nSender: Commander / Recipient: Operator 6O

2.text_: ■ Re:[TOP SECRET] Capture and Destruction of\nYoRHa Units 8B, 22B, 64B\nSender: Operator 6O / Recipient: Commander

4.text_:
■Confidential Mission Details
Sender: Operator 6O Recipient: 2B
* Note that this is a direct order from the Commander. Forwarding is
forbidden.

1.text_: Development Log, Pt. 1: There have been lots more invasions by\nmachines lately, so they named me head of Weapon R&D. I'm going\nto come up with something that puts them in a world of hurt!

2.text_: Development Log, Pt. 4: A sword that cuts in a single stroke?\nSome kind of hammer? I just don't know what to do here. I mean,\nI don't just want to kill them—I want to scare them.

3.text_: Development Log, Pt. 8: It's been months. Development is as\na standstill. My friends are taking me out tonight, which I'm\nhappy for; I know they'll have some good ideas for me!

4.text_: Development Log, Pt. 18: I KNOW this will scare them, because it\nscares us androids! We'll annihilate them with it and use our victory\nas a tribute to all the other androids I tested it on.

1.text_: This white lance has an interesting history. After leading its\nprevious owners to tragic deaths, it came into the possession of\na boy concerned for his sister. But soon he, too, met a bad end.

2.text_: After his death, the lance was lost. Humanity had ceased to exist,\nafter all, and so for ages uncountable it lay forgotten and exposed\nto the elements.

3.text_: But though the cities humanity had built fell to ruin, wildlife\ncontinued to thrive. One day, a lost fawn found a dull, dirty lance\nin the middle of a grassy field.

4.text_: Taking it in its mouth, the fawn brought it to the foot of a great tree.\nAnd when the animal died and night vanished from the world, the\nlance continued to wait patiently for a new owner.

1.text_: This dark lance has an interesting history. After leading its previous\nowners to tragic deaths, it came into the possession of a father\nconcerned for his daughter. But soon he, too, met a bad end.

2.text_: After his death, the lance was lost. Humanity had ceased to exist,\nafter all, and so for ages uncountable it lay forgotten and exposed\nto the elements.

3.text_: Machines slowly began to build a civilization atop the ruins of the\nhuman one. One day, a machine found a dirty lance in the corner of\na factory and decided to make it his treasure.

4.text_: The machine locked the lance away in his room. But his memory had\nbroken down during the war, and he was no longer able to open the\nlock on his own. CAN ANYONE GET ME OUT OF HERE?

1.text_: Some fools make strength their goal, even though it's what you\naccomplish with strength that matters. And yet, I wish to become\nstronger all the same.

2.text_: Some fools discriminate against sentient machines, even though\nthere is no difference between them, and therefore no purpose to\nit. And yet, I discriminate all the same.

3.text_: Some fools are bound to rules, even though rules without will are\nnothing but a curse. And yet, I am bound to the rules all the same.

4.text_: Would things be different if I had strength? If I was like\neveryone else? If I had freedom? Would I be better without this\nheart at all? Regardless, I will stay here to the end.

1.text_: This spear belonged to the first elder sister whose memories\nI inherited. I take care of it, but it's obviously way more banged\nup than it used to be.

2.text_: My original elder sister had a sword akin to this spear. They made\nmany weapons for us—weapons for weapons, as it were—and\nthis spear is one of the first.

3.text_: I can't be sure of the details, because it's just deduction from\nmultiple memories... But I want to improve this spear.\nBecause they didn't make it to fight the enemies I face.

4.text_: There. This should be more effective in battle—it's certainly\nmuch better than it used to be. You know, making and fixing\nthings is kind of fun!

1.text_: A man attempts to climb a massive, unconquered mountain. It's as\nif he searches for the boundary between life and death through the\nharshness of nature and finds purpose in it.

2.text_: Suddenly, a blizzard sets upon him. He feels for the gift from his\ndaughter in his pocket and continues to climb, letting the warmth\nfrom her present carry him.

3.text_: When he finally reaches the summit, he beholds an illusion of the\nwife he left behind. He then swears to make it down the mountain\nand return to the warmth of his happy family.

4.text_: Only the faintest hint of life remains in the man after he slips\ndown the cliff. The image of his daughter and his pregnant wife\nscatter into darkness. Is it regret? Or a brief moment of joy?

1.text_: The scars of war mar the desolate city. As plants reach out from\ncracks in the asphalt, a girl clad in a black coat quietly stares at\nthe sight.

2.text_: Nature's growth covers the city's wounds. The girl steps off her\nmotorbike and approaches the plants, for she's spotted a glint\nunder the shade of leaves.

3.text_: The object is a damaged sniper rifle. As she gazes at the\nbent barrel, she realizes her own spear resembles the gun to an\nuncanny degree.

4.text_: She might be imagining the similarities, yet she can't throw the\ngun away—so she stuffs it into the bag on the back of her motorbike\nand rides off.

1.text_: This luxurious mansion known as Rose Manor in the city of A was\nhome to Mr. U and his wife, who had generously opened their\ngarden and its cornucopia of roses to the neighborhood children.

2.text_: When a young maid went to work at the manor and never came\nhome, her fiancé asked police to search the home, and a reluctant\nMr. U allowed it.

3.text_: The maid was finally found wandering lost in the cellar, which had\nbeen remodeled so many times it was now a maze. The police would\nlater describe it as feeling "off."

4.text_: 23 MISSING CHILDREN FOUND IN ROSE MANOR!\nThis afternoon, the children were freed from their prison,\nand Mr. U and his wife were taken into custody.

1.text_:
Once there was a soldier who had lived through hundreds of
battles and was known as a legend. The reason for this name was
his brawny frame, clean spearmanship, and the strange weapon he
carried that housed the power of flame.

2.text_:
The spear's awesome power could burn away bullets and arrows in
flight. One day, he and his army burned another village to the
ground. His fellows were thrilled about the mission, for they knew
they would not lose with him there.

3.text_:
One night at a banquet, his squadmates asked for the secret to
his survival. "No matter how powerful your weapon," said the man
proudly, "it means nothing if you do not have the skill to wield it.
What's important is to train every day."

4.text_:
Soon thereafter, his entire army was wiped out by a plague from a
village they had burned. The common folk, who heard of the events,
turned them into the following lesson: "What's important is a healthy
body so you avoid illness."

1.text_: The mermaid's first love was a young human man. He stole her\nheart as he paddled a small boat across the vast sea, and she\nwondered what she could do to bring him into her life once more.

2.text_: The mermaid prayed to the god of the sea, who caused a tsunami\nthat pulled an entire oceanfront village under the waves—but the\nman she loved was not there.

3.text_:
The mermaid prayed to the god of the sea again, and this time the
diety caused a wave that sunk an entire inland town. But while
the man she loved was there, he was immediately overwhelmed by
the tsunami and drowned.

4.text_:
But the mermaid was satisfied, for she was young and naive, and
felt one final look was good enough for a first love. Eventually,
she found another man and fell in love again, and soon was
praying to the god of the sea once more.

1.text_:
Deep in the forest lived a boy who could talk to inhuman things.
This power caused his parents to abandon him in the woods, and
he walked a lonely road. But in place of human parents, he was
raised by a spirit known only as The Master.

2.text_:
When the boy came of age, he came across some villagers being
attacked by a monster. The kindhearted boy ran to The Master for
help, who in response bestowed upon him a spear that housed a
strange power.

3.text_:
The boy used the spear to dispatch the monsters threatening the
villagers. And though he was happy to help, the people all feared
him—for not only did he wield a strange power, he could not even
speak the human tongue.

4.text_:
Rumors soon spread that the boy's rage over being abandoned had
caused the monsters to appear, so the villagers went to his forest
and burned it down. And when the smoke cleared, only a single,
blackened spear remained.

1.text_:
Legends tell of a time long, long ago when the god of light created
six weapons and scattered them across the world. One such 
weapon, a spear, was said to always hit its mark. But it remained
lost, and its legend faded from memory.

2.text_:
One day, a girl from a mountain village fell into a ravine while
chasing a rabbit. She soon became lost amidst the dense trees and
rough stones, and sobbed bitter tears over how much she missed
her mother and father.

3.text_:
Suddenly, a dirty spear fell beside the girl. When night came, she
hugged it close as she slept, which was soothing to her. In the
morning, she found the spear a few paces away— and picking
it up, set off in the direction it pointed.

4.text_:
Each evening, the spear moved a few paces from the girl. And after
three days and nights of following it, she found her village and was
reunited with her parents. To this day, her father uses the spear as
a handy compass when hunting.

1.text_: Rendezvous, meeting, fate, origin, encounter, beginning, delirium,\njoy, fortune, favor, destiny, happenstance, blessing, confrontation,\nsource, origination, genesis, alpha, omega, bliss...

2.text_: ...romance, courtship, agape, affection, hope, fondness, passion,\nattachment, infatuation, mania, idolization, devotion, flattery, love,\nkiss, flavor, hunger, desire, heat, longing...

3.text_:
...suffering, difficulties, trouble, agony, doom, injury,
torment, sorrow, regret, melancholy, grief, anguish, distress,
heartache, tears, pain, misery, disaster, worry, misfortune,
calamity, tribulation...

4.text_: The note that accompanied the body ended with a single word: Vile.

1.text_:
Pure white blankets the peaks. Stars hang in the sky. Snow swallows
sound, creating a place governed by silence. Upon these mountains
that rejected all life, there had long lived a tribe known as the
Silversnow Wolves.

2.text_:
Those who lived at the foot said winter cursed the mountains,
and feared the cold and death it brought. That is why the Wolves
stayed there: so they might live free under the constant shadow of
oblivion.

3.text_:
Those who lived at the foot said winter cursed the mountains,
and feared the cold and death it brought. That is why the
Wolves stayed there: so they might live free under the constant 
shadow of oblivion.

4.text_:
One day, a man touched by their way of life made his way into the
mountains so he might join them. But he did not notice the crunch
of footsteps in the still, and became but another source of food for
the Wolves.

1.text_: I was caught in a human trap and set to fight. My first battle was\nagainst a human male called a "slave." The man was weak, and I\ncrushed him as he made to flee.

2.text_:
My condition for freedom was to survive a hundred battles.
My fiftieth fight was against a swarm of poisonous insects.
The agony of their stings coursed through my body, but I still
managed to crush every last one.

3.text_: Despite my trials, thoughts of my family gave me hope.\nMy ninety-ninth battle was against a titan like me. He only wanted to\nreturn to his home, but I wanted the same—so I crushed his head.

4.text_:
When the final battle began, the combatant who appeared in 
front of me was the very wife I thought was home awaiting my return.
Cursing my own powerlessness, I ran my wife's spear through
my own heart.

1.text_:
In a time of endless war, great numbers were sent to die on the
fields of battle. In an attempt to bolster its forces, the nation
issued a decree that any child old enough to hold a weapon would
be drafted into service.

2.text_: And so, expressionless officials went from town to town, tearing\nscreaming children from the arms of their mothers and dragging\nthem off as their sobs echoed across the land.

3.text_:
The children were brought to a base and trained in the art of
warfare. Within a month, they knew how to threaten, how to
torture, and how to kill. The only thing left was for them to put
these lessons into practice.

4.text_:
The first person they killed was their commander; then they went
and slaughtered the other officers. For the children's enemy was
not some faceless foreign country, but the adults who had
stolen their lives away.

1.text_: The spear was a favorite of a man who hailed from a family of\ntorturers and excelled at bringing pain to others.

2.text_: How does one bring extra pain to others? More fear? More suffering?\nEach expression of agony excites him, and causes him to chuckle a\ndark and eerie laugh.

3.text_: Yet this man—as all men—was powerless against time. And when\nhis end was nigh, he was determined that God would not kill\nhim, and so took his own life instead.

4.text_: The spear was passed from torturer to torturer, but all who\ninherited it discarded it soon after, claiming the weapon emitted\na dark and eerie laugh whenever they looked at it.

1.text_:
There was once a vile military unit called the Red Devils.
They were a terrifying bunch, made up of the most heinous criminals
in the world. Good and evil held no meaning for them; there was
only flesh, blood, and bone.

2.text_:
One member of the force was a pike-wielding woman who had taken
lives from a young age until it was as natural as breathing.
She had chosen her weapon for no particular reason—so long as
it could kill, it would do.

3.text_:
As a child, she'd lost her parents to a burglar. What had been
taken could never come back, and no one reached out to her.
From this period of loneliness and despair, she learned the
true workings of the world.

4.text_: And so she killed, plundered, and lived—just the same as what had\nhappened to her. This was how she kept going. After all, there was\nno one left to fix her mistakes and lead her back to a better path.

1.text_: Only one person calls me Eliza, and she is our original. She is\nthe one we are to protect in the event of an emergency.

2.text_: She always offers to get whatever we want, even though we are\nweapons who desire nothing, Yet she still pays us more mind\nthan she needs to.

3.text_: She tells us to count on her. Her insistences are unreasonable;\nwe are disposable, and unlikely to disappear so long as she lives.

4.text_: We cannot understand our original's actions. But on the day her\nscreams shake the facility, I finally understand why she cares\nso much for us.

1.text_: A tribe of dragonfolk once lived in a remote rural area. They were\nan especially strong people, so humans relied on them to dispatch\nthe monsters that appeared across the land.

2.text_: The one in charge of slaying monsters was the dragonfolk chief.\nHe proudly wielded a spear that had been handed down through\ngenerations, and made a name for himself in countless battles.

3.text_: One day, he faced a poison-spitting fiend. The next, a monster that\nsummoned lightning. The next, a creature to which blackbirds\nflocked. All for the sake of the humans who relied on him.

4.text_: In truth, humans had chased the dragonfolk off because their\ncorpses turned into horrible monsters. But the chief knew nothing\nof this, and kept using the spear to end the lives of his kin.

1.text_: Twins were born that day. They were very close, and made the same\nchoices in everything they did—including favorites, sleep, and play.\nBut one day, the younger fell ill during a pandemic.

2.text_: Ten years later, with the younger twin bedridden, the two no\nlonger spent every moment together. Yet the elder twin still loved\nhis brother, and made certain to visit him every day.

3.text_: One day, the younger twin asked his brother to do one last thing\ntogether. The elder knew this meant the end was near,\nand searched for something they could do as one.

4.text_: The next day, a nurse found the twins dead on the bed, a forked\nspear piercing both of their hearts. For they had sworn to leave\nthe world as they entered it: together as one.

1.text_: The god of spring spoke:\nI shall breathe life into the plants and trees.

2.text_: The god of summer spoke:\nI shall cause life to grow with strong sun.

3.text_: The god of autumn spoke:\nI shall grant a harvest, the nourishment of life.

4.text_: The god of winter spoke:\nI shall bring death to all that cannot survive me.

1.text_: Long ago, there was a court chef who was close friends with the\nuncle of the older sister to the shop owner whose main branch was\nnext to the instrument store that made the bard's lyre.

2.text_: The chef made whimsical cho voir-style zolgoi where the thulsorza\nwas boiled for three days and three nights similar to Buffonne-style\ntoltaffin dumplings garnished with otinuls vi laconte.

3.text_: The queen said it tasted like sludge from the root of the tree in\nthe center of the forest at the base of the mountain as seen from\nthe best views at the castle at the edge of the field.

4.text_: The chef despaired at losing the queen's favor and took a halberd\nand pierced his own throat and the queen was sad because she\nmeant to compliment him but it was too late so she kept eating.

1.text_:
Deep in the mountains, far from civilization, sits a lonely ruin.
It is a haunted mansion, one said to house the ghost of a woman
killed by bandits. Fearful of the ghost, none have dared set
foot in the house for an age.

2.text_:
In the city, a curious adventurer hears the tale of the house.
He immediately takes up his family heirloom—a spear that can put
spirits at ease—and makes for the ruin in order to grant the
ghost peace.

3.text_: Days later, he returns from the ruin in high spirits. When asked,\nhe says only that he successfully put the woman to rest, and\npeople noticed that the ghost never again showed itself in the ruin.

4.text_:
Years later, a different ghost is sighted there. The adventurer
again readies his spear and goes to dispatch the creature,
but returns crestfallen—all he'd found was the ghost of a baby
that looked exactly like him.

1.text_: There was once a couple that lived on a snowy mountain. The wife\nhad long been known for her great beauty, something the husband\ntook much pride in.

2.text_: One mid-winter, the man ventured deep into the mountains to hunt.\nAnd at the bank of a frozen lake halfway up the mountain,\nthe man encountered the goddess of snow.

3.text_: "I preside over beauty," she said, "and shall grant you beauty for\nall eternity." But the man pleaded with her to give this gift not\nto him, but his wife.

4.text_: The man returned home to find his wife encased in an impenetrable\nblock of ice. He immediately returned to the mountain in search of\nthe goddess, but never found her again.

1.text_: I wield my spear with eyes glowing red.

2.text_: I wield my spear to seek the place commanded of me by the voice.

3.text_: I wield my spear as I feel pain nestle deep in the recesses of\nmy heart.

4.text_: I wield my spear because I have finally found the path I must walk.

1.text_: January 31\nMy job is to throw scrap metal in a furnace.\nEvery day. Every damn day. I am SO bored!

2.text_: February 8\nGot nothing else to do, so I collected some scrap metal\nand forged a spear. Turned out pretty nice, actually.

3.text_:
February 9
My manager found out about my spear and chewed me out—
said I'd been slacking off. Pretty rich to accuse me
of slacking when he's paying all of us peanuts.

4.text_:
February 25
Heard the plant is closing down. Whatever.
This spear is what earned me the big bucks—
everything my manager saved, in fact!

1.text_:
A boy and a girl struggle to survive in a polluted land. The foul
air ruins everything—people, trees, grass, all of it. Children born
there fall sick and die without ever having a chance to
create a future.

2.text_: When the girl realizes she is ill, she tells the boy her dream:\nShe had once seen a white flower in a picture book, and wants to\nbehold it for real before she died.

3.text_: The boy has never seen a flower, but searches desperately all the\nsame. He crosses blockades, fords streams, and enters forbidden\nlands. Finally, he finds a flower that is brown, withered, and ugly.

4.text_:
Hesitantly, he offers the flower to the girl, who closes her eyes
and strokes the petals with one shaking hand. "It's...beautiful,"
she says as a tear rolls down her face. She then slips into
oblivion, still clutching the flower.

1.text_: Once, there was an insular country that forbade free \nmovement across its borders. Most who attempted to enter \nwere denied, and as a result, barely any knew of it.

2.text_:
The process was strict. After a thorough background check, 
the applicants were called to the border and questioned by an
officer who wielded a great spear on her back—who would 
then decide on the spot.

3.text_:
One month, five applied for entry and were denied. Four left 
without quarrel, but the last was run through by the officer 
when he drew a weapon and attempted to fight his way 
through.

4.text_: The officer was, in fact, the country's princess, and the \ninspections a plan to help her find a strong husband—a plan \nshe carries on with to this very day.

1.text_: A couple built a schoolhouse in a developing country and took in\nunderprivileged children. They fed them, educated them, and raised\nthem with love, as though they were their own.

2.text_:
One day, a boy abandoned by his parents arrived at the
schoolhouse. The couple embraced the boy and gave him bed with
soft blankets. Soon, his wounds began to heal, and he was
even seen to smile.

3.text_: Eventually, the boy nervously approached the couple and asked\nthem to be his real mother and father. With strained smiles, they\npatted his head and said, "We are everyone's mother and father."

4.text_:
The next day, children at the schoolhouse began dying off one by
one, until only the smiling boy remained.
"Now will you love only me?" he asked the couple as a lone black
bird took off into the sky.

1.text_: The god of spring spoke:\nI shall breathe life into the plants and trees.

2.text_: The god of summer spoke:\nI shall cause life to grow with strong sun.

3.text_: The god of autumn spoke:\nI shall grant a harvest, the nourishment of life.

4.text_: The god of winter spoke:\nI shall bring death to all that cannot survive me.

4.text_: She might be imagining the similarities, yet she can't throw the\ngun away—so she stuffs it into the bag on the back of her motorbike\nand rides off.
