1.text_: Ten years ago: His home was unsafe, his parents murdered in\nexchange for coins. As he no longer needed his spear to fish, he\ntook weapon in hand and set out in search of the killer.

2.text_: Five days ago: The city was in a state of neglect, as usual. Every day, someone else died—a stranger, a neighbor, a friend. Why does it always have to be this way? he lamented to himself.

3.text_: Yesterday: He found the man who killed his parents and plunged\nhis spear into the criminal's heart. Finally, after ten long years, his\nfamily had been avenged.

4.text_: Now: <i>What if that was the wrong man? What if someone else\nwas the true killer?<i> With spear in hand, the man grins wildly\nand sets off in search of the killer.

1.text_: One day, a man's daughter was captured by enemy soldiers.\nDesperate, he purchased a weapon with a shady history and\nset off to save his child.

2.text_: Suddenly, the shady weapon said to him,\n"Me and myself will help you." The young voice reminded him\nof his daughter, and the flames of his anger rose higher.

3.text_: Though battered and bruised, he managed to save his daughter.\nAs tears rolled down his cheeks, he told the weapon,\n"You saved my family. Thank you."

4.text_: "Family"? Never heard of it. I don't need anyone besides me,\nmyself, and you. No one, got it?\nAll this world needs is me, myself, and you."

1.text_: Once, in a kingdom far away, there were three laws imposed on the\npeople by the royal family. Violating a law would result in harsh\npunishments or even death, but most citizens still praised them.

2.text_: The first law was "Do not steal." This obviously included theft\nand burglary, but also life—and once there was even a dispute as\nto whether "stealing one's heart" counted.

3.text_: The second law was "Do not harm another's reputation." Though it\nseemed a kindly law, it was actually enacted to avoid damaging the\ndignity of the kingdom through language or insult.

4.text_: The third law was a secret, which the people loved, for they felt it\nmade everyone more considerate. Alas, no one realized it was done\nsimply so the royal family could execute whomever they wished.

1.text_:
There once lived a small, shabby bird in a far-off forest.
This bird was often ridiculed by its fellows for its dull and scruffy
wings, but the bird paid no mind as these wings allowed it to
soar through the great sky it loved so dearly.

2.text_:
Unhappy seeing such filthy wings in their sky, the other birds
made a proposal. "Let us see who can fly the highest. Win and
our wings will be yours; lose and you must leave this forest."
Wishing for beautiful wings, the bird accepted.

3.text_:
The match begins and all the birds take to the sky.
As they climb, the air thins and the currents grow unpredictable,
and before long only the small bird and a sea eagle remain.
The small bird reaches its limit, and is unable to go on.

4.text_:
The small bird crashes toward the ground. Just before it meets
land, it is lit up by the sun and engulfed in flames. The beauty
with which it soared through the air as fire ravaged its body was
said to rival that of the legendary phoenix.

1.text_: TYPE-4O BLADE INSTRUCTION MANUAL: Before use, confirm all\nattachments are accounted for. Use the tester on initial\nstart-up to check for energization.

2.text_: WARNING! Refrain from using this product if you suffer from\ndefects in mobility or calculative capacity. Do not wield it\nfor cases outside its intended use.

3.text_: CARE INSTRUCTIONS: After battle, use a soft cloth and light\ncleaning liquid to remove any dirt. In case of physical damage to\nthe product, please consult your Operator.

4.text_: DISCLAIMER: This product does not conform to military product\nsafety standards. YoRHa R&D is not liable for injury or death\nsuffered due to use of this product regardless of cause.

1.text_: I am the emperor of this great nation. My governance is absolute,\nmy word law—though I doubt any would dare speak their mind\nbefore a blade so great as this. Do you not agree?

2.text_:
This wonderful blade can sever a dozen heads in one blow,
so neighboring countries dare not touch my lands. Ah, but this
makes life dull; I must let my blade indulge in blood sometimes,
you see.

3.text_:
Let us eradicate the nation to the south! I hear there are many
lovely women there, so take whichever you like. Meanwhile, I will
cut through the advance guard and see how many heads I can
claim.

4.text_:
A dozen enemies surround me, so with one fell sweep,
I will... wait. What are you doing? Why have you turned your
blade on me!? You make thirteen, which means my blade...
will...not...

1.text_: I remember skin, pale and soft.\nNot taut and cold like this.

2.text_: I remember a voice, clear and melodic.\nNot low and gravelly like this.

3.text_: I remember hair, long and glossy.\nNot short and wiry like this.

4.text_: I remember eyes, lonely and sad.\nNot ones that crave me like this.

1.text_: Humans are extremely selfish creatures that oppose any who are\ndifferent. Thus do they make displays of their power,\nwith winners holding sway over losers.

2.text_: Humans revere the continuation of their own species—they are\nattracted to one another and breed. Thus do more come into being,\ngiving rise to new victims.

3.text_: Humans are unable to exist alone—they constantly seek connections\nwith others. Thus do their gatherings become disorderly mobs\nwithout purpose.

4.text_: Humans are foolish and unsalvageable creatures. Is there any need\nto allow them to live?\nNo. All humans deserve to die diE dIe DIe DiE DIE DIE

1.text_: We were wed as the minister arranged. We did so for our family,\nand for future generations. I had no interest in love or romance,\nand had no reservations toward this marriage.

2.text_: I remember how unwelcoming she looked when I first laid eyes on\nher. This aura made her hard to approach; I hesitated to even\nspeak with her. How does she view this marriage? I often wondered.

3.text_:
She surrendered her young life for the sake of her house,
so I understood if she shut off her heart. I pitied her, and tried
to be considerate and understanding. We were husband and wife,
after all.

4.text_: But she remained detached; more like a doll than a living being.\nThinking of her that way, my efforts started to feel foolish. What\nhad I been hoping for? I should have just done this from the start.

1.text_: Once, there was a village that suffered from a dragon. Stalwart\nmen attempted to drive the beast hence, but its flames reduced\nall who came near to ash.

2.text_:
The village was on the edge of destruction when the people heard
rumors of a man who wielded a mighty greatsword. His weapon was
said to hold the power of flame, and had been used to slay
countless fiends.

3.text_:
The villagers tracked down the swordsman and begged him for
succor, for they hoped his sword could stand against the dragon's
flame. And though they knew it was a heavy request, the man
quickly and confidently agreed.

4.text_: As they hoped, the greatsword resisted the dragon's flame.\nBut the swordsman, alas, did not—instead turning into ashes on\nthe wind and vanishing without a trace.

1.text_: Once, there was a curious wind spirit who sought to befriend a\nhuman girl. But the spirit could not speak, so it tried to think of\nother ways to communicate.

2.text_: First, it made a breeze. The girl's skirt fluttered, causing her\nto frolic and laugh merrily—which only made the spirit want to\nplay with her all the more.

3.text_: Next, it created a blast of wind. Trees bent double, and the girl\nshut herself inside to weather the storm. What could the spirit\ndo to make her come out?

4.text_: Finally, it created a tornado that knocked down the house—\nbut alas, it also blew the girl clean away, killing her.\n...Oh dear. Perhaps that was a bit too much.

1.text_: A cursed greatsword was enshrined in a cave off the coast.\nWhen a reckless man found it and reached for its hilt, a strange\nvoice called out.

2.text_: Next thing he knew, he was surrounded by the ghosts of people\nwho had died in battle, all with the same question on their\nlips: "What is the point in fighting?"

3.text_: But he could not remember why he fought. Why he had come. What\nwas he even doing there.

4.text_:
The dead took his hand and led him further into the cave,
until he came across a clear spring that emanated with a soft
blue glow. And when he set foot into the spring, he fell down,
down, down into that glorious light.

1.text_:
Legends tell of a time long, long ago when the god of
light created six weapons and scattered them across the world.
One, a greatsword that heightened one's will to live, was at
the peak of a mountain where none survived to claim it.

2.text_:
One day, a noble-minded knight attempted the peak. As he got
closer, he found countless corpses of adventurers who had
come before, still pristine from the cold. He politely buried them all
before finally arriving at the peak.

3.text_:
There he found a greatsword emitting a warm light, but the poor
knight scarcely had any energy left; his rations were gone,
and he had not eaten for ten days. As he reached for the sword,
he knew he would soon perish in this place.

4.text_:
The moment he took sword in hand, power raced through him and
he wanted to live. To eat. He could eat anything now.
No—he wanted to eat. He had to eat. So the knight climbed quickly
down the mountain to undo the graves he had made.

1.text_: The girl sat alone in a dark cell for many a year. It was\na darkness that sapped all sense of time, so she simply\nwaited for each moment to pass.

2.text_:
The only time she saw light is when she was given food. Her door
would open a crack, and a blinding ray would come streaming into
the room. She lived for these moments; indeed, they were all that
gave her life meaning.

3.text_:
She wolfed down her food and resumed waiting for the light.
That was her life; she knew nothing else. But one day, a man
appeared who had learned of the girl's plight and felt great
sympathy for her.

4.text_:
He opened the door and extended his hand to her, at which
point she promptly bit it off. She proceeded to eat every
last scrap of the man, then folded her legs beneath her and
resumed her vigil for the light.

1.text_: The last drop of water will soon be lost to the blazing sun.\nEveryone knew it was coming to this, but we did nothing. Instead,\nwe let inaction eat away at our hearts.

2.text_:
This camp is a forsaken place, and people who take refuge here
have no other choice. I gave the last of my water to a child
earlier—her vacant eyes seemed to moisten just a bit as she
drank it down.

3.text_:
Those who die in war don't get a happy ending; they just perish in
misery, their final wishes forgotten. What would a god of this
world even look like? What expression would be on His face as
He watches us?

4.text_:
My time as an observer ends when I take up a sword. Do people
see me as a reaper as they surrender their lives to me without
resistance? With a blank expression, I swing one last time and
finish my task.

1.text_: Blue is the color of spring; of budding life.\nBlue is the color of seas; of overflowing life.\nBlue is the color of life—but it is an ignorant color.

2.text_: Red is the color of summer; of blazing flame.\nRed is the color of blood; of flooding vitality.\nRed is the color of life—but it is a lost color.

3.text_: White is the color of autumn; of rich abundance.\nWhite is the color of mist; of impeding boundaries.\nWhite is the color of life—but it is an innocent color.

4.text_: Black is the color of winter; of death and the end.\nBlack is the color of sin; of the defiling of existence.\nBlack is the color of life—the fate of everything.

1.text_:
Once, a titan appeared at a remote village on the verge of
collapse. Seeing that the people faced certain death,
the kindly titan dug up the earth, forming a river and
saving the village.

2.text_: Would you bring wood so we might have houses, Titan?\nThe titan effortlessly carried the timber to the village,\nand had the little houses built in no time flat.

3.text_: The wolves we hear at night frighten us greatly, Titan. The titan\nfollowed the howls and found the wolves' den, where he snuffed\nout the lives of every last one.

4.text_:
You're amazing, Titan! I want to be like you someday! With a
wide smile, the titan picked up the person who made this request,
squashed them flat, and stretched out the remains so they would
be just the right size.

1.text_: Once, a swordsman discovered a special ore deep in a cave.\nHe knew it held a great power, and brought it to an engineer\nso he might craft a greatsword with it.

2.text_: The blade was large and heavy, and too blunt to cut even paper.\nBut it was sturdy and never chipped, so the swordsman slowly\ngained renown for the way he battered foes to death.

3.text_: The swordsman's country called him a hero and awarded him a\nmedal. They also planned to reward the engineer, but that man had\nmixed feelings about his prize.

4.text_: "The ore is magical," said the engineer.\n"But if one does not possess the ability to use magic,\nmy weapon is little more than a crude bludgeon."

1.text_:
Why did this happen to me? I'm just a damn engineer! This war
took everything. My wife—my pregnant wife? I don't even know
if she's alive. All I have now is revenge, which is why
I devoted myself to weapon development.

2.text_:
My goal was to create living weapons. Weapons that thought.
Learned. Evolved. I would use them to inflict pain on the people
who took everything from me, but first I needed actual people to
serve as my materials.

3.text_:
I found children who had lost everything and altered them.
One by one, they were reborn as weapons. They, too, have surely
lost things precious to them, and I know that together, we will
turn our hate into power.

4.text_:
But when the work was done, I found a necklace that belonged to
my wife. A groan escaped my lips as I saw it, but my weapons made
no response. Once I had collected myself, I ordered one of
them to kill me.

1.text_:
His greatsword was the embodiment of our nation's justice.
He returned safely from any battlefield; he was a hero to the
people, and moreso to us soldiers. But one day, he vanished—and
now I am looking for him.

2.text_:
As I searched, I encountered plenty of rumors. And while some had
the ring of truth, I did not want to believe them— because the
man in those tales was an entirely different person from the hero
we all knew.

3.text_:
Sadly, the rumors turned out to be true: Our hero was now
wandering the land killing people indiscriminately. Would I be
able to kill him for his crimes? After all, this man had led me.
Saved me. Loved me.

4.text_:
I found him in the ruins of a church. When I asked why, he said
he killed in the name of justice. As the dust on the floor began
turning black with my blood, he whispered,
"I will enact justice until my last breath."

1.text_:
There was once a soldier who wielded a greatsword for a
war-loving king. He fought day after day, year after year,
and loved every moment of it, gaining great wealth and
fame as a result.

2.text_: The only thing he loved more than battle was climbing the castle\nwalls and looking down at the city, for he loathed the common folk.\nThat was why he gave all to the service of his king.

3.text_: After many battles, the man was named a general and summoned\nby the king. His heart sang as he walked to the throne room, for he\nknew his liege would have a great role for him in the next war.

4.text_:
But the king told the man the next war would be fought by
clockwork men and dismissed him. The next day, he leapt from the
wall and became a smudge on the ground that the common folk
simply ignored.

1.text_:
INSTRUCTIONS: PAGE 1
◆ Chop any part you like into pieces. Chop, chop, chop!
This will be easier if you take a really big swing,
but watch out for all the blood!

2.text_:
INSTRUCTIONS: PAGE 2
◆ Use the weight of the sword to crush stuff!
Beating the body to a pulp will bring great mental anguish
to the subject. Be sure the affected part doesn't fester.

3.text_:
INSTRUCTIONS: PAGE 3
◆ Apply pressure by squeezing between the ends of the blades!
The subject's head is perfect for this. You can adjust the
pressure with the handle, but be careful not to go too far!

4.text_:
INSTRUCTIONS: PAGE 4
◆ It's...blank. Looks like I'll be the fourth person to
be punished with this sword. I think they're testing out
methods, one person at a time? How have I ma—

1.text_: There was once a vile military unit called the Red Devils.\nThey were a terrifying bunch, made up of the most heinous criminals\nin the world. They were sent into battle for a single reason: to kill.

2.text_: One member of the force was larger and stronger than all the rest.\nHe wielded a fearsome rod, and laughed loudly as he used it to\nbreak apart buildings and people alike.

3.text_:
The man's father had taught him to let go and laugh when he was
having fun, so he did just that. He never recognized his acts as
a crime, because he was simply enjoying himself. It had been
this way since the day his parents died.

4.text_:
Driven to madness at the discovery of his wife's affair, his
father sat beside her corpse and laughed until his throat was raw.
The boy could not understand; he could only imitate his father
and how much he enjoyed himself.

1.text_:
An order of knights once served a royal family. Its captain was
so skilled with a sword, he could take on any number of enemies
and emerge victorious. People called him "The Iron Mask" for
the helm he always wore.

2.text_: In truth, however, the king had ordered the captain to never\nremove his helm. And while he obeyed his liege, no one else in\nthe order knew about his command.

3.text_:
Though few noticed, the king actually hated the captain.
But as he lacked the skill to defeat him, he instead forced
him to wear a cramped, uncomfortable iron helm that covered his
entire face.

4.text_:
The reason for this hate was petty indeed: The captain was a
handsome man, and the queen had grown infatuated with him.
And though that occurred decades ago, the king had never been
able to forgive him for it.

1.text_: "It's my fault he died. I have no right to call myself a knight."\nThe moment that thought came to me, a girl approached with a\nflock of blackbirds in tow.

2.text_: "Please help!" she cried. "Wicked men are chasing me!"\nWould saving her redeem me? I gripped the greatsword he left\nto me, took her hand, and ran.

3.text_:
"Give us the girl, unless you wish to die in her place!"
To surrender my life for another is no choice at all, and I was
reunited with him in heaven far more quickly than
I thought possible.

4.text_: "Good. That went well. Here's your money." You killed my father\nand claimed his sword: the only keepsake he left behind.\nIt is not yours to hold. Farewell.

1.text_:
There was once a mountain known as Mt. Nevermore, so called
because none who went there ever returned. Many legends surrounded
the place, such as tales of man-eating demons and hot springs that
could cure any illness.

2.text_: One day, a woman's husband went missing. When she searched\nhigh and low and found no trace, the other villages began\nwhispering about how he had been swallowed by Mt. Nevermore.

3.text_:
Grasping this faint ray of hope, the woman ventured onto the
mountain. As she walked deep into the dense forest, she eventually
stumbled across her husband collapsed in a pool of blood on
the ground.

4.text_: The woman was relieved; she had stabbed her husband, but he had\ngotten away. As she thought about if he had been trying to find\nthe hot spring, she heard something very large moving behind her.

1.text_: "Understood." The word contains no emotion for me.\nI have said it hundreds of times.

2.text_: I am a puppet that obeys orders to kill. I snuff out emotions as\nI snuff out lives, and will do so until the day I rot away.

3.text_: The age we live in determined my station from the moment of\nmy birth—which is why I burn to at least live as myself.

4.text_: "Understood." The day I said that to the girl, I felt an\nexhilaration unlike anything that had ever come before.

1.text_: My family was everything to me. I believed it my mission to\nprotect my wife and daughter—but when the Flowers appeared,\nthey stole my daughter's life away in the blink of an eye.

2.text_: People are closely managed in this world corrupted by the Flowers.\nWe're forced to fight so we might take our lives back—and though\nI am practically a prisoner, I gleefully wield my sword for revenge.

3.text_: We captives wipe out the Flowers. My wife and I survive the\nfight, and share our joy together. But in that moment,\nthe world stands still.

4.text_: That's when I remember how we are managed; that nothing is\nfree of binds in this world, not even emotion. And that it was people\nwho took my wife's life.

1.text_:
There was once an android soldier who did not fear death.
He wielded a great blade and wandered from battle to battle,
learning how to use his endless life by watching
others being stolen.

2.text_: One day, the soldier found a gorgeous red rose blooming on the\nbattlefield. It stole the android's heart in an instant,\ncausing emotions he thought lost ages ago to come gushing forth.

3.text_: The android fought for the rose, cutting down anything that\nmight cause it harm. He was overjoyed to finally be fighting to\nprotect something, and not to simply take a life.

4.text_: When peace finally came, the android realized the red rose was\nthat color because it was splattered with blood. But he still\nwanders the battlefield in an endless search for beauty.

1.text_: A cage surrounds me. Walls stop me. My vision is occluded\nby black. I wander the dark, not knowing the way nor my\ndestination. Only my feelings stand out amidst the inky gloom.

2.text_: I am made to realize I have stopped wanting. My heart was\nonce spurred on by something long ago, but what?\n I have forgotten; I don't even realize I have done so.

3.text_: The paralyzing dark melds into my cavernous heart. \nMy perception and senses warp; my emotions lie languid. \nI am akin to but a husk, but I feel a sense of relief nevertheless.

4.text_:
That day, I break through the mud and see a white flower in
bloom. It is far, far too bright, and before I know it, I feel
tears rolling down my cheeks at the sight of it reaching
toward the light.

1.text_:
There was once an organization of ninja that served a shogun.
Assassinating enemy lords, silencing allies, executing
vengeance—these were their tasks, and no matter how difficult they
were, they always succeeded.

2.text_:
There was one woman in the organization. She chose the path of
the shinobi because she longed to be like her mother, who was a
skilled ninja. She also choose to wield twin blades in order to
better follow in her footsteps.

3.text_:
One day, she was ordered to murder her mother, who knew too
much to be left alive. And while a ninja cannot refuse a task,
she wailed as she did the deed, dulling her blows and causing her
mother great pain.

4.text_:
Afterward, she reforged her swords and her mother's into one
long blade. As if trying to run from it all, she tried to forget her
mother's dying face and swore on her sword that she would
always kill in a single blow.

1.text_:
There was once a kind nobleman. Though he ruled the city,
he never abused his status; he performed his own fieldwork and
chores like any man, and his subjects loved and respected
him greatly.

2.text_: The man was always with his people, working hard to make life\nbetter for them. When the waterwheel broke, he repaired it with\nhis own hands. When beasts attacked, he ran to the front lines.

3.text_:
But even the finest man cannot stand against nature, and one
season a drought came that withered the crops. Even though the
nobleman had money to purchase food, there was none for
sale anywhere.

4.text_: In an act of charity, the man set himself on fire. The hungry\npeople wept before swarming the corpse. Taking a lesson from this,\nthey then began burning and devouring one of their own each day.

1.text_:
You know that one hermit who lives outside town? Old guy who
stares out the window when it rains? I hear he was a combat medic
way back in the day. Guy has seen some things,
let me tell you what.

2.text_:
This one time, a soldier was brought in covered head to toe in
burns. By all rights the guy should have been dead, and the
army must have thought so as well, because they decided he was
beyond help and didn't treat him.

3.text_:
Next morning, they all had to move out, which meant leaving
the burned man behind. The medic—then just a kid—wanted to give
him some water, but the army didn't want to waste any and
ordered him to march instead.

4.text_:
I reckon the old guy regrets that to this very day, even
though it was objectively the right decision. That's why
he stares out that window when it rains: he's praying it
falls on the soldier, wherever he is.

1.text_: Our immigration fleet had been sailing the stars for months \nwhen we were beset by pirates. My little sister was killed, and \nI now fight with the sword that slew her.

2.text_: When I use the sword, I hear a strange voice in my head—a \nvoice that analyzes the current situation and tells me how to \nturn any fight in my favor.

3.text_: I obey the voice without question, fighting in a zen state. \nFor some reason, it sounds like my sister. I think she wants \nme to join her.

4.text_: Finally, I find the pirate who took her life. The sword orders \nme to kill and I obey—but the moment I do, the voice falls \nsilent, never to speak again.

1.text_: People saw the weapon as a useless stick; too heavy for any \nto wield, and too bulky to kill. None even knew why it was \nmade in the first place.

2.text_: The weapon was melted down and turned into armor and \nshort swords. Though light, the armor was impenetrable, and \nthough thin, the swords were unbreakable.

3.text_: The swords made mountains of corpses; the soldiers in armor\nwere invincible. Each time a life was taken, those doing the \nstealing soared with excitement.

4.text_:
But the armor would not come off and the swords could not 
be dropped—and soon the armaments drew together like 
magnets, rolling the soldiers into a hunk of metal bigger than
the original stick.

1.text_: The child couldn't get along with his peers. He was bad at \nexpressing things through words, and soon developed a bit \nof a complex with speaking.

2.text_: As his poor speech caused him to place distance between \nhimself and others, society treated him as an outcast, causing \nhis loneliness to grow.

3.text_: As an adult, he chose a life as hired muscle, knowing none \nwould find fault with silence in such a profession so long as \nhe killed swiftly and well.

4.text_: When enemies begged for their lives, he felt human for the \nvery first time. And as he basked in this bliss, a flock of black \nbirds gathered around him.

1.text_:
There was once an android soldier who did not fear death.
He wielded a great blade and wandered from battle to battle,
learning how to use his endless life by watching others
being stolen.

2.text_: One day, the soldier found a gorgeous red rose blooming on the\nbattlefield. It stole the android's heart in an instant,\ncausing emotions he thought lost ages ago to come gushing forth.

3.text_: The android fought for the rose, cutting down anything that\nmight cause it harm. He was overjoyed to finally be fighting to\nprotect something, and not to simply take a life.

4.text_: When peace finally came, the android realized the red rose was\nthat color because it was splattered with blood. But he still\nwanders the battlefield in an endless search for beauty.

1.text_: My birthday is on Christmas! Grammy and Grampy are coming over,\nwe're eating yummy food, and I get presents and wear pretty\nclothes! It's sooo much fun!

2.text_: My birthday is on Christmas, so I'm going to invite\nfriends over and eat cake. Oh, and I got presents for\neveryone so we can have a gift swap!

3.text_: This is my first Christmas with my boyfriend. I've always\nhated having my birthday on this day, but his proposal to\nme made it perfect.

4.text_: Fifty years hence, my birthdays aren't so special anymore—but the\nchildren like them, so I do what I can. Still, I've likely only a\nfew more before I join you, so please...wait for me.

1.text_: Lady Two is truly kind. She rules the Land of Sands with love for\nher people, and the children love her back—although I am\nundoubtedly the one who loves her the most.

2.text_: Lady Two is truly powerful—why, she can defeat monsters with her\nbare hands! I would be no match for her...

3.text_: Lady Two is truly faithful—she works so hard in the name of her\nsister's ideals and her people! And she is so straightforward that\nI...I almost went mad with worry.

4.text_: Lady Two is truly... She is kind. Too kind. That is why I should not\nhave made her kill the children. That's what I was there for.\nNo matter what happens, Lady Two, I...

1.text_: It is the leaves of a plant that make way for the beautiful flowers\nthat follow. This is the woman's bloodline—she is of those who\nexist in secret.

2.text_: Her life knows no peace, no normality. Though she acts the part,\nsuch gaps are far too wide to ever be spanned.

3.text_: The seaside sun? The smiling people? Such things are too\nbright for her. So she turns away from the light and opens her\nparasol instead.

4.text_: A passerby says that her parasol, open as it is toward the sky,\nlooks like a sunflower. How beautiful it is, they say. How utterly\nperfect.

1.text_: It is said those who wield this sword will not know fear. Once one\ngrips the handle, heat rises from the depths of their heart and\ntransforms the user into a dauntless lion.

2.text_: It is said those who wield this sword will not know defeat. The\nuser does not bend the knee even to a force of tens of thousands,\nand prevails over all who would attempt them harm.

3.text_: It is said those who wield this sword will not know aging. Once\nequipped, the sword takes away time as the wielder knows it,\nand throws its wielder into eternal battles.

4.text_: Become a lion. Never defeated. Never aging. Rumors beget more\nrumors, and now all manner of tales swirl about this sword. But no\none knows any who have actually wielded the blade.

1.text_:
You are clad in white for the ritual of self-slaughter—for as
your master is dead, so must you follow him. I stand beside you,
silent, ready to remove your head and ease your suffering at
the end.

2.text_: Your whole life was a neverending battle. You were a\nstranger to both love and wonder, and never realized\nwhat I felt for you.

3.text_: Even as your petals scatter, you are beauty.\nThe crimson that blossoms from your stomach\npaints the wound the color of a dusky sky.

4.text_: Though you seek swift relief, I beg forgiveness.\nJust now, while you yet linger in this world,\npermit me to embrace you.

1.text_: I strike the object before me. Once... Twice... Three times.\nPerhaps as a final show of resistance, a faint smile crosses its\nlips and it says to me, "You're insane..."

2.text_: After I awoke, I verified that I possessed memories. But are\nthese memories truly mine alone? I had to know for sure.

3.text_: Something about the memories I possess seems too convenient.\nToo ready-made. There are insufficient in proving that I am my\nown being. Am I truly who I think I am?

4.text_: My once-fleeting doubts grew to consume me. I want to be the\nonly me that exists. I raise my fist in the air, then smash it down\non the object that looks just like me.

1.text_: This is a story from when I was a child. There was once a\nterrifying demon with black wings who landed in our village and\ncommitted such atrocities that all were struck dumb with fear.

2.text_: We had no choice but to flee our home. But when we turned\naround for a final look, we saw people had appeared who\nwere attempting to fight the demon.

3.text_: The valiant group finally bound the demon and ended its life.\nRelieved the threat over, we decided to return to our village.

4.text_: Several days later, our village was struck by a natural disaster,\nkilling many. Some claimed it was the demon's revenge, but I think\nthe demon was trying to save us in the first place.

1.text_: Long ago, a beautiful man with white wings came to Earth.\nAll claimed he was a servant of God, and began scrambling over\neach other to request of him their desires.

2.text_: One lamented his horrid appearance.\nOne prayed her thieving tendencies might be cured.

3.text_: The masses all fell to their knees and gazed up at the man,\nwho looked down upon them with a merciful smile.

4.text_: Then he gouged out their eyes, cut off their arms, and lopped off\ntheir heads, believing this salvation. And hearing no more pleas,\nthe angel smiled proudly, his work complete.

1.text_:
I borrow compatible parts from other broken machines and
install them, but something happens—someone that's not me is
in my head. I try over and over to remove it, but there's a
barrier in the way.

2.text_:
Now I act in ways I don't recall—like how I was apparently
collecting shells on a beach today. Extraneous actions are
frowned upon, but no matter how hard I try, I can't delete
the other person.

3.text_: I finally surrender to my situation, and now my room is slowly\nfilling up with shells and bits of glass. The durations for which\nI remain myself grow ever shorter...

4.text_: Once, when my memory returns, I find a picture in my room.\nIt is made from colorful glass and shells, and shows two machine\nlifeforms holding hands. I do not understand what it is trying to say.

1.text_: Day Adrift #1\nMy body aches. Where am I? And how did I get here in the\nfirst place? Geez, I'm so forgetful lately—I'd better start a diary!

2.text_: Day Adrift #2\nWhoa, this place is so pretty—look at the glittering sand!\n...Huh? Your name is Mama? Hello, Mama! I'm Emil!

3.text_:
Day Adrift #3
So this is a dark scarecrow, eh? Whoa! Birds flew out of it!
Don't scare me like that, Mama! ...Huh? I'll like the next one?
I dunno about that.

4.text_:
Day Adrift #4
Mama said everything I could ever want is behind this door,
but... What? I need gems to open it? Okay, I'll go find some
sparkly rocks!

1.text_:
The man beat people. Seeking to change his life of violence,
he took what little money he had, purchased a pair of hand
protectors, and became a combatant in an underground
fighting ring.

2.text_:
The man continued to beat people. He defeated all comers with
his signature move: a single punch from his white-hot right fist.
Soon, he had won so many fights that he found himself a
wealthy man.

3.text_:
The man stopped beating people. In addition to his
newfound wealth, he now had a beloved wife and daughter.
So he began thinking of a way he could keep his family happy
that did not involve violence.

4.text_: The man began beating people again. He became a torturer,\nand now pummels with a smile. "I'll beat them until they confess,"\nhe is heard to say. "But this is not violence. This is justice."

1.text_:
One terribly stormy day, as fierce winds howled among thick
clouds, a young boy was struck by lightning. Though all feared
him dead, he was miraculously unharmed—and in fact,
the lightning awakened in him an ability to scry the future.

2.text_: The boy's father immediately set out to turn a profit from\nhis son's power, and soon people swarmed from near and far in\nsearch of his prophecies.

3.text_:
The boy understood how he was being exploited, and quickly
came to loathe both his father and those who sought his wisdom.
Eventually, a day came where he saw a vision of what would
befall his own town, but he kept it to himself.

4.text_:
The next day, a great storm swept through town and claimed
many lives—including the boy's father. And as he listened
intently to the nearby crashes of thunder, he thought to
himself, "I wish the lightning would strike someone."

1.text_:
Once, a boy was born to a troubled family in a poor fishing
village. His house was filled with the sounds of squabble. Yelling.
Screaming. Sobbing. It continued day and night, without pause and
seemingly without end.

2.text_: Though the boy covered his ears, he never knew silence.\nAnd on days when he could stand the fighting no longer, he would\nflee the house and spend hours staring at the sea.

3.text_:
When he finally reached adulthood, he stole his father's own
weapon and beat him to death with it. He expected this would
finally bring him silence, but he still heard his terrified final
screams echoing in his ears.

4.text_:
The man left the house and threw himself into the sea.
And though waves crashed and the ocean was quite lively, the man
somehow found it calming. Finally at peace, he closed his
eyes and let himself drift away.

1.text_:
Legends tell of a time long, long ago when the god of light
created six weapons and scattered them across the world.
One such weapon, a gauntlet, lied buried and forgotten in
a vast desert populated by a destitute and alien people.

2.text_:
This tribe made a living selling ore, trading bagfuls of it for a
few meager coins. One day, as they toiled away at a dune,
a member of the tribe dug deep and pulled a pair of shining
golden gauntlets from the sand.

3.text_:
They decided to offer the gauntlets to their queen, hoping both to
display their loyalty and perhaps gain permission to come live in
the city. But the cruel queen merely took the gauntlets and
cast the people back into the desert.

4.text_:
The queen gazed longingly at the gauntlets. But the moment she
touched them, they turned to sand and crumbled away. At the
same moment, back in the desert, the tribe found that all the ore in
their sacks had turned into gold.

1.text_:
Though born to a noble house, I was, to be blunt, a loser.
Though my older brother shared my blood and genes, he was
terrifically talented, and the difference between us seemed to
horrify my parents.

2.text_:
My brother had won battles against a dozen men, whereas my
weak body could barely hold against one. My father, appalled by
this, heaped unending abuse on my mother,
insisting I could not be his child.

3.text_:
Though we had been given the same schooling, my brother was a
keen military mind, whereas I could not grasp even the most
simple combat tactic. This horrified my mother, who turned her
back on the truth of my existence.

4.text_: They did not acknowledge my birth. They did not acknowledge\nmy life. They did not acknowledge my existence. And that is why\nI feel no need to acknowledge my own bloody hands.

1.text_: Most titans love raising a ruckus, but I am an exception.\nWhenever the others get too rowdy, I put 'em in their place with\nmy fists. One good punch is enough to do it, most days.

2.text_:
The other day, I saw a group of men harassing a woman. They were
being too loud, so I gave 'em hell with my fists. I just wanted
some peace and quiet, but the woman instantly became infatuated
with me.

3.text_:
The woman and I had a son. She would scream at the child to
discipline him, so I did what I had to to keep her quiet.
Also, the child likes to cry over every little thing, which
is incredibly infuriating.

4.text_: Huh? Uh oh. He's not moving. ...Well, can't change it now.\nI didn't mean to do it, but Dad just would NOT shut up!

1.text_:
Halfway through its demolition, an apartment complex was
suddenly abandoned. But there, amidst the tangle of steel beams
and exposed concrete, lived a single old woman with no relatives,
no memories, and nowhere else to go.

2.text_: But the longer she remained in the wreckage, the clearer her\nmemories became. One day, she recalled that a man used to\nlive in the apartment with her.

3.text_:
Here are the stairs my husband dashed up ever day. There is the
landing where our daughter played. If not for the accident,
we would have grown old together. So why have I forgotten?
Why am I the only one left?

4.text_: As she pondered these questions, the old woman wrapped the\ncable from the crane around her neck and kicked the chair away\nso she might finally see her family again.

1.text_:
My family hails from an ancient and honorable lineage, and we have
presided over justice here for generations. My father, an upstanding
man, was granted his title by the king himself—and as his son,
I must honor that legacy.

2.text_:
My father has passed justice on many criminals, and it is he who
taught me that most people are naught but trash. If I hope to
bring beauty into this world, I will need to work hard to fulfil
my own duties.

3.text_:
On my first day on the job, the knuckledusters on my fists crack
open a criminal's forehead, splitting it like a melon. As an unearthly
noise spills from his mouth, his darkened eye sockets gaze
out blindly.

4.text_: I feel a fathomless darkness in those terrible eyes, and... No.\nI did the right thing. I acted in the name of justice. This is\nyour fault! I'm right! I'm not wrong! I am innocent! I am just! I am—

1.text_: There was once a boy called the "little weapons trader." His\nparents had been lost to war, so he cared for his infant sister by\nscouring empty battlefields for weapons to sell to a local buyer.

2.text_: Each day, the boy walked the scorched earth looking for\nitems to sell, sometimes finding only scrap the kind buyer would\ntake anyway. But one sad night, an air raid took his sister's life.

3.text_:
With his reason for living gone, he bought a grenade from his
buyer. He didn't know if his enemy came from another country or
his own, but he planned to run at them with grenade in
hand regardless.

4.text_: But when he pulled the pin, nothing happened; the kind buyer,\nnot wanting him to die, had sold him a dud. As the boy stood\nthere in a daze, the buyer slowly came up and embraced him.

foodfoodfoodfoodfoodfoodfoodfoodfoodfoodfoodfood

Did you know it would be like this?

1.text_:
There was once a vile military unit called the Red Devils.
They were a terrifying bunch, made up of the most heinous
criminals in the world. Enticed by the thought of wanton murder,
they were abased to being mere tools for killing.

2.text_:
One member of the force was a warrior fascinated by battle.
The tension of intimate, close-up combat entranced him, so he
became a hand-to-hand fighter that he might get even greater
enjoyment from life.

3.text_:
A moment's hesitation would cost him his life, and only on that
knife's edge of death did he feel alive. So he spent his days in
the heat of battle—and yet, it was a boy his complete opposite who
brought about his eventual ruin.

4.text_:
It was a slaughter—nothing like the kind of battle the man enjoyed.
And yet, this end satisfied him. So overpowered he could not even
struggle, the feeling of death blotting out his world made him
feel more alive than ever before.

1.text_: One day, my master purchased a red rose blooming in a vase.\nThe merchant claimed the rose would never wither so long as it\nremained in the vase. I wonder if this is true.

2.text_: But the rose was not a bright enough red for my master, so he\nasked me to do something about it. I diligently watered it, gave it\nfertilizer, and set it in the sun, but the color did not change.

3.text_: Enraged, my master claimed I was a useless lump—but was he not\nat fault for purchasing something so suspect in the first place?\nThis unreasonable attitude made my own ire rise.

4.text_: I struck and killed him with the vase. Seeing my chance, I dipped\nthe rose in his blood. "There, sir!" I cried. "It is now the beautiful\ncolor you have been yearning for!"

1.text_: Once upon a time, there was a scary monster who\nloved to eat human dreams.

2.text_: He ate and ate the dreams so he could become human.\nAnd when a little girl gave him her dreams, he ate those as well.

3.text_: After a time, the monster decided that once he turned human,\nhe would become the girl's friend.

4.text_: But when he did turn human, the girl became a monster in\nexchange and went somewhere far, far away. The End.

1.text_: A rich girl lived in a beautiful mansion in a far-off city.\nThough her closet was crammed with beautiful outfits her\nparents had bought her, she took terrible care of them.

2.text_: One day, she decided to wear a white linen dress adorned \nfrom tip to toe with lace. But when she spilled some tea on it,\nshe simply tore the dress off and threw it away.

3.text_: The next day, she pulled out a beautiful ebony dress.\nBut she quickly decided it was too plan, and tossed it out\nwithout ever trying it on.

4.text_:
Her discarded clothes were eventually put up for sale at a
small bazaar. A local girl was amazed at the quality of the
black dress; it was like nothing she had ever seen. 
But a pauper like her could never wear such a thing.

1.text_:
Fear is a primal instinct of the animal called man.
"If people want to avoid fighting," thought the man, "then the
fear of dying in battle would be a more effective deterrent than
trying to negotiate peace."

2.text_:
If the enemy runs in fear of death, there is no need to fight.
So he killed every enemy who stood against him, racking up a
massive body count in the hopes people would begin to 
associate him with death itself.

3.text_:
Soon, he dyed his armor red and decorated it with skulls so
he might be feared even more and therefore avoid battle.
But he had yet to encounter an enemy who feared him, so he
continued to kill everyone he saw.

4.text_: He killed and killed but still no one feared him.\nSadly, he never realized he was killing everyone who\nmight spread the tale of his terror.

1.text_:
My research led to uncountable people dying in battle.
This troubled  me at first, but I eventually stopped thinking
about it. Then they brought me a new test subject: a middle-aged
man, fat as a pig.

2.text_:
My orders were to find a way to make his body produce a
mysterious toxin, but the man was...confusing. He didn't seem to
have a human ego, and when he spoke, he only grunted and
begged for food like an animal.

3.text_:
I observed the man as I experimented on him, and over time,
my contact with him re-awakened the humanity I had long ago.
This led me to wonder what would happen to the man when
the experiment was over.

4.text_:
At that moment, I remembered why I became a researcher—and
it wasn't to kill people. So I cancelled the experiment.
People were furious and I had to flee, but I feel much better
because— Oh, wait. It's feeding time!

1.text_:
Father works hard, but always says the same thing: "I was a
competent technician before it all went to hell." Today he's off
looking for useful junk and muttering that same thing. Meanwhile,
I'm little more than skin and bone.

2.text_:
Father is in a good mood today; he says that if he can complete
this new job, we'll never want for anything again. He looks so
full of life! Just watching him is making hope bubble up inside
my own heart.

3.text_:
I stare at a row of shiny black machines. Father is proud; some
very important folks are coming to collect them soon. He says
he'll buy me whatever I want once that happens, and I'm almost
dizzy with anticipation.

4.text_:
The pool of blood blots out my dreams. After the people took the
machines, they killed my father and burned his notes. I wet my
dry throat with tears and blood, but I know this will be a thirst that
stays with me forever.

1.text_: The sprinkles glitter in the dark. They look so yummy!\nBoy, am I ever hungry!

2.text_: There's a round, poofy donut! And fluffy cotton candy! Oh, I can't\ntake it anymore!

3.text_: The sprinkles and donut and cotton candy were all so tasty!\nI wanna eat the blue gumball next!

4.text_: The spacetime distortion was identified as a black hole that\ncontinues to expand rapidly. Scientists say it will reach us soon,\nso we must develop plans to escape our planet as soon as possible.

1.text_: Black rain falls. The powerful droplets splash the mud,\ndirtying my feet. The boundary between myself and the other\ngrows hazy.

2.text_: Someone emits a red scream on the black earth. But no one listens.\nBecause if one allows the red to touch them, their silhouette will\nbe revealed.

3.text_:
None can abandon this black land, which is why they hate the
ones who alienated the outsiders that lay waste to this leveled
ground. The rain falls silently, turning the earth into thick,
dark mud.

4.text_: Flapping wings sneer. Though far from the ground, the spots in the\nsky remain black. But no one will acknowledge it. Soon, black\nspots fall to earth, and stripped feathers sink into the mire.

1.text_: I'm a proud dragon, not some servant for a puny human child like\nyou to order around! Do you hear me, you ugly wench?

2.text_: Oh my gosh, could you BE more boring? ...Hmm? Oh, come on—it\nwas a joooke! No need to get huffy. Good lord, how can a wimpy\nthing like you possibly hope to govern this city?

3.text_: Look, we're both women, so you can lean on me if\nyou want. ...Huh? Why didn't I say that when we first met?\nC'mon, just leave a dragon to her whims, will you!?

4.text_: C-can't believe...I would've ever sacrificed myself for someone else.\nIf you weren't such a kind, stupid blockhead...m-maybe this would\nhave ended up differently...

1.text_: I found a strange object while exploring the depths of this cave:\nan odd, glossy sphere. I can't figure out what it's made from,\nsave that it's some sort of elastic material.

2.text_: Oh! It bounces if I hit it with my hand! Well, that is just delightful.\nI think I'll throw it against the wall here for a bit.

3.text_: After playing for a while, I investigate the sphere further and\nrealize it's full of air. I wonder what would happen if I let it out.

4.text_: Oh, what a lovely scent! It reminds me of something a noblewoman\nwould wear. Sadly, my torch is flickering and my rations are gone,\nso maybe I'll just stay here and smell it for a while...

1.text_: This power is for stopping my sister.

2.text_: This set of words is for calming Weiss.

3.text_: This magic is for saving Kainé.

4.text_: This ___ is for loving ___.

1.text_: "Just make sure you don't mess up next time."\nEveryone said that; they said feeling sorry about the\npast won't change it. But my scars remain. They never heal.

2.text_: "Work hard now for a brighter future."\nSomeone said that; they said there's no point worrying about the\nfuture. But if I don't know what the future holds, what do I work on?

3.text_:
"We need to take it one step at a time."
You said that to me; you said time wouldn't wait for us.
But I still don't know where I should go, so I pray that
time stands still.

4.text_:
"■■■■■■■■■■■■"
I think I said that. I wait between a set past and an invisible
future, and time leaves me behind. It all becomes too late.
That is why I...

1.text_: One day, a group of young men came to an all-knowing sorcerer.\nThey were all smitten with the most beautiful woman in town, and\neach asked him how they could make her his lover.

2.text_: The sorcerer said, "You will clean my house, forage for herbs,\nand run 1,000 laps through town. I will teach whomever returns\nfirst a spell to infatuate the woman."

3.text_: The trial was bitter work, and the men soon realized that was\nthe point. For the sorcerer wanted them to rely on their own\ncapabilities, not his magic.

4.text_: But when the men returned to thank the sorcerer, they found him\nwith the woman of their dreams, having bewitched her with a\npotion he made from the herbs they gathered.

1.text_:
A lone boy stood sobbing before a gate. He had hoped to 
attend the land's most prestigious school of magic, but they 
rejected him because he was too poor and lacked the proper 
arcane equipment.

2.text_: But the boy would not give up on his dream. Since he could \nnot purchase equipment, he snuck onto the school grounds \nand found a dirty staff discarded in the trash.

3.text_:
Several years later, he graduated from the school at the top 
of his class and was rewarded with a beautiful new staff. 
He immediately tossed his old one aside and began to walk 
the path of a sorcerer in both name and deed.

4.text_: Sadly, however, once he discarded the old staff, he lost his \nability to perform magic—and after several fruitless years, \nthe once-promising sorcerer took his own life.

1.text_:
In the ancient time, an earth spirit created a quiet lake so it 
might take its rest. It loved the lake, and appreciated how no 
fish or insect disturbed its quiet. But one night, a lone baby 
was brought there and abandoned.

2.text_: The baby howled for its mother all through the night. But the \ncries of a human mean nothing to bird or beast, and the poor \nthing eventually grew weak and passed.

3.text_:
The earth spirit found itself pitying the child, and caused an 
earthquake that severed the land and connected the lake with 
a vast ocean beyond. This brought fish and seabirds to the 
lake, and it soon became a vibrant and lively place.

4.text_:
The baby's soul was delighted, for it now had friends in the 
form of birds, fish, and flowers. After confirming that all would 
be well, the spirit let out a satisfied sigh and set off to find a
new place in which to rest.

1.text_:
A fisherman saw something strange in his net one day; upon 
pulling it from the water, a staff tumbled out. He took the 
weapon home, cleaned it as best he could, and hung it up as 
a kind of decoration.

2.text_:
When dawn broke, the man saw that the staff was gone and 
had been replaced by a beautiful girl. He found this odd, but 
was entranced by her loveliness, and thus the two came to 
live together.

3.text_: One day, their house caught fire. The man sat quietly, \naccepting his fate, but could only watch in horror as the girl \nstood up and threw herself into the flames.

4.text_:
Suddenly, the blaze was gone. And where it had burned, a 
single staff lay on the floor. He picked it up, thinking of the girl 
as he was overcome with melancholy, before throwing both 
himself and the staff into the sea.

1.text_:
Legends tell of a time long, long ago when the god of light 
created six weapons and scattered them across the world. 
One such weapon, a staff, sat abandoned beside a creek that 
quietly wound through a remote nation.

2.text_: Adults, thinking it driftwood, paid the staff no mind. But one \nday, a young boy who dreamed of being a swordsman picked \nit up and began training with it every day.

3.text_:
As he swung the staff about, it would sometimes shoot out 
gouts of flame or hunks of ice, which shocked the adults. 
In this way, without even realizing it, the boy eventually awoke
a great magical power within himself.

4.text_: The boy grew up to become a world-renowned archmage. \nYet his desire to be a mighty swordsman never waned, and \nstayed buried in his heart to the day of his death.

1.text_: Some time ago, a boy was offered up to the gods. Taken to a \ndark grotto and leashed to an altar, he was intended as a \nsacrifice to sooth their righteous anger.

2.text_: Yet the boy did not hate his people, for he knew that his \nsacrifice would allow many more to live. This was the way of \nthings. This was right.

3.text_:
In a way, he was almost looking forward to it. He alone would 
know the faces of their gods, who elsewise did not deign 
appear before humans—and this simple fact was enough to 
satisfy him.

4.text_:
But the gods never came. Instead, the boy stayed tied to the 
altar as his consciousness slowly slipped away. So when a 
hungry beast appeared, he assumed it was a god, and a 
smile spread across his face as it devoured him.

1.text_: You can brandish this stick. Doing so will let you threaten \nothers.

2.text_: You can prod with this stick. Doing so will let you keep others\nin check.

3.text_: You can strike with this stick. Doing so will let you attack \nothers.

4.text_: You can pray with this stick. Doing so will let you heal others. \nThis isn't just any stick—it is a staff.

1.text_:
The iron bars that separated the land were a symbol of its 
segregation, and those who lived beyond the wall were not 
even recognized as human. But the land was lean for each 
side of the bars alike, and it drained the hearts of all.

2.text_: The man had a daughter, but could not see her. She was \nbeyond the wall—was she even alive? "This is all because of \nthose damn bars... No. It's because of the people's hearts."

3.text_:
The man wailed, for he could not understand why it had come
to this. His wish was the same as any parent: to embrace his 
own child. With his own death looming, he swore to do 
anything to see his daughter once more.

4.text_: The authorities arrested a man who had crossed the bars. \nTo them, he was no better than a beast, so he was quickly \nkilled and thrown into the same grave as his daughter.

1.text_:
The Silversnow Wolves lived in tall mountains to the east. 
The name was given to them by people who lived nearby, as 
their own language lacked any particular moniker by which to 
distinguish themselves.

2.text_:
This was likely due to the Wolves' ideology and doctrine; they 
lived in grim, wintry conditions where snow fell year-round, 
and had cut themselves off from society entirely. As such, 
they had no need to assert their own identity.

3.text_:
It is said they spent their time contemplating their own 
mortality—a practice started by the matriarch who founded 
the group.Such anecdotes have not been confirmed, however, 
and some doubt this matriarch even existed.

4.text_:
Wilder tales say the matriarch had superhuman strength, ran 
faster than the wind, and could kill a bear unarmed. While 
these tales stretch credulity, the extinction of the Wolves is 
said to have been due to this great woman's death.

1.text_: An injured titan wandered into a small, desolate village. \nThough the people there feared him, a kindly old woman \ntended his wounds and brought him back from death.

2.text_:
But the strain of healing the titan was too great, and the old 
woman found herself in much pain afterward. To thank her, 
the titan took on day-to-day chores, fetching water and 
preparing meals for his host.

3.text_:
When the day came for the titan to leave, he fashioned a 
mighty staff for the old woman. Though his clumsy hands 
made the staff almost difficult to wield, she was elated by the 
gesture nevertheless.

4.text_:
One day, some soldiers tracked the titan to the village. Afraid, 
people spoke of the titan and his connection to the old 
woman. They burned down her home, and the staff went on to
 claim many lives as a weapon of war.

1.text_: A special ore was found at the bottom of a ravine. It contained \na powerful magical element, and soon was being processed \nand used in all sorts of miraculous ways.

2.text_: One woman, concerned for those dying in battle, made a staff\nout of the ore and used it to heal. She gave her charity freely \nto all: old, poor, and enemy alike.

3.text_:
The staff's power was great. It could heal all manner of 
wounds—including broken bones, common colds, lacerated 
wounds, and stomach aches—and people everywhere soon
flocked to her for aid.

4.text_:
The woman was eventually named a saint and made a 
symbol of peace. Thus was a heavily-armed nation founded
—one whose soldiers could endure any wound and continue 
on without dying.

1.text_:
I don't know color, for I've always been blindfolded.
I don't know song, for I've no one to speak with.
I don't know rain, for I've never been outside.
But such things brings me comfort.

2.text_:
I don't know light, for I've killed many people.
I don't know the sea, for I was born as a tool.
I don't know love, for my life has no value.
But how am I supposed to die?

3.text_:
I don't know night, for I've always had bright dreams.
I don't know lies, for I cover my ears in terror.
I don't know pain, for I have always been protected.
But I need to find my end quickly.

4.text_:
I don't know God, for no one has given me one.
I don't know sin, for my blood is sullied.
I don't know life, for everyone is dead.
But I am glad you listened to me.

1.text_: There was once a far-off country that created history. \nThis country gave us three things: The past, the future, and \nweapons which embody great justice.

2.text_: The past shows how we were born and how magnificent we \nare. We who share this past came to walk the same path.

3.text_: The future is full of hope, and we who shared this future came\ntogether to make it a reality and create a nation.

4.text_:
This country we brought into being came across another 
nation that knew a different past, and had hopes for a different 
future. And so our people raised their weapons and fought to 
the death.

1.text_: Once, a man became enamored with a beautiful woman. But \nhe belonged to the people who lived in the water, and so\n could not call out to her.

2.text_: Every day, the man watched her walk into the sea and \nrelease a handful of flowers for her dead husband, who she \nhad lost in a flood some time before.

3.text_:
One day, hoping to follow her husband, the woman walked 
into the sea and never emerged. And though the man 
mourned her most greatly, no one came to offer the woman 
flowers.

4.text_: Finally, the man followed his beloved and took his own life. \nHis body became a staff adorned with flowers, and was a \ngift to the woman at the bottom of the sea.

1.text_: A young prince lived in a kingdom ruled by a war-loving king. \nHe wore magnificent clothes, and did his best to help in \npolitical affairs so he might be of use to his father.

2.text_:
Many people lived in the sprawling town at the foot of the 
castle, and the kind-hearted boy thought long and hard about 
how they—and all people—might find happiness instead of 
conflict.

3.text_: a new war began, the king addresses his army, who roared \nmightily in response. As they set off, the boy prayed as he \nalways did that they might return safely.

4.text_:
But the boy was ill, and knew his father thought him weak. 
He also knew the people thought him a tyrant due to the 
actions of the king. In the end, he was but a puppet who 
danced on strings.

1.text_: I have committed a grave crime, and will apparently be taken \nto another place and tortured. I can only imagine what kind of \nterrible punishment awaits me there.

2.text_:
We've reached our destination—it appears to be a church of 
some kind. There's a man with a staff who looks like a priest 
over there. Do you think I'll be able to repent to God and end 
my life with some kind of salvation?

3.text_:
I begged for mercy. Begged. I know there's little point in doing
so after all this time, but I will continue to pray with all my soul 
if it lifts the burden of this sin. Save me, God! Save me! 
Save me! SAVE ME!

4.text_:
Imagine my horror when I learned the priest was, in fact, my 
torturer! Ah, but it makes sense such a man would be divine 
in my circumstance. To think of all the time I wasted praying 
to God instead of praying to him!

1.text_:
There was once a vile military unit called the Red Devils. 
They were a terrifying bunch, made up of the most heinous 
criminals in the world. Their screams tore through the world 
like a muddy stream, and people named that sin.

2.text_:
One member of the force was pathologically high-strung. 
Once bothered, he could not stop until the offending item or 
thought was purged. He chose the baton as his weapon 
because he did not wish to be splashed with blood.

3.text_:
His first murder was committed because someone spoke to 
him and their voice lingered in his mind in an irksome way. 
After that, his sensitivity only grew, much like water backs up
behind a damn.

4.text_:
Someone coughed. Someone breathed. Someone touched 
his hair. He killed for many reasons, and though he was highly
decorated within the force, he finally grew to find even 
silence grating, and killed himself to end it.

1.text_: There were once orphans who'd lost their homes and parents \nto war. A kindly priest took them in and gave them a home, \nbut his church was poor, and he relied on donations to get by.

2.text_: When the donations stopped trickling in, the trio went hungry. \nWith no other choice, the priest began dirtying his hands with \ncrime, but the children caught him in the act.

3.text_: "I know you may not forgive me," said the priest, "but I do this\nso we might continue to live together. The only other choice is\ndeath. Do you understand?"

4.text_:
The orphanage received many large donations to aid the 
children with no guardian. And as black birds soared above 
while the children ran cheerfully in the fields, the priest 
slumbered eternally underfoot.

1.text_: My father taught me that I mustn't get attached to life.

2.text_: My father spread word that death wasn't to be feared.

3.text_: My father explained there was salvation after death.

4.text_: My father gasped in his final breaths that he didn't want to die \nwithout me.

1.text_: The wind from the east tells of a reunion.\nIf I soar high—so high—will I see everything?

2.text_: The wind from the south exalts ambition.\nIf my wings beat strongly—so strongly—will you watch?

3.text_: The wind from the west warns of discord.\nIf I fly fast—so fast—will I be able to escape?

4.text_: The wind from the north signals a parting.\nWhen—oh when—will I find you?

1.text_: I walk through a dusty wasteland. Sand blows into my hair. \nMy mouth. My eyes. I wonder then if he is all right, and when \nI turn to look, our eyes meet.

2.text_:
Hoping to brush it off, I quickly ask if we're going the right way. 
Directions are near to meaningless in this hellscape; dust 
obscures your vision, and the barren land extends to the 
horizon in every direction.

3.text_: He responds that we are, indeed, on the right path. As I \nmurmur a word of thanks, a thought occurs to me: "This road \nis just like life."

4.text_:
Our destination may be right before our eyes or a thousand 
miles away—there is no way to know the answer. Yet the one 
thing I do know is this: He is the only reason I keep moving 
forward without losing myself.

1.text_:
I was killed—or at least, I should have been. But the image of
my husband and his warmth are no dream. 
Though something feels terribly off, we are still overjoyed to 
reunite.

2.text_: Deserters like us are treated as outsiders. We all know the \nfacts, but still want to take our lives back, so my husband and\nI throw ourselves into battle in order to win our freedom.

3.text_: When the fight is over, we learn the truth: We were simply...\nthings created for war. Upon hearing this news, \nmy consciousness goes black.

4.text_: I am given a final choice, but I doubted there was an answer \nto the question. Everything we do is managed by someone \nelse, after all.

1.text_: A new light. I pray it will illuminate the night, and one day, the \nworld.

2.text_: A distant light. As it makes vows to the heart, the young light \nreaches out to it.

3.text_: A hollow light. The light clouds in sickness and torment, \nforsaking its dreams.

4.text_: A faint light. But it still shines; I pray it will burn always.

1.text_: The girl dreamed of becoming a doctor. She wanted to heal \nher mother's legs, which had grown weak from overwork.

2.text_: Day after day, the girl shunned play so she could diligently\nstudy. But everyone around her poked fun, for they did not \nthink one such as her could become a doctor.

3.text_: But the girl did not give up; she stuck with her studies and \ngave it her all. Eventually, she won over her doubters, and all \nwho knew her came to support her.

4.text_: Centuries later, she finally realized her wish. She exchanged \nthe worn-out parts and healed her mother's legs, and went on \nto be considered the finest android doctor in the land.

1.text_: There was once a staff that had been passed down through \ngenerations of a royal family. It was said that any who carried \nthe staff into battle would be guaranteed victory.

2.text_:
So had regents ever commanded their soldiers with the staff 
and used it to shepherd the country to great victories. But the 
staff had no power over the slow vagaries of time, and 
eventually its might was lost to the ages.

3.text_:
Recently, however, the staff was uncovered during an 
excavation. The country's rulers immediately brought in 
researchers from far and wide to divine the power of the staff 
and how it led always to victory.

4.text_: Their discovery was terrifying. The staff had a power that \ncould control both soldiers and wielder; it was a mighty crook \nthat produced perfect sheep who felt no fear.

1.text_: A noblewoman lives in a nation where station of birth \ndetermines all. Her entire life has been spent in a blessed \nenvironment, a stranger to failure and hardship.

2.text_: Eventually, however, she meets a common man who is \nsmitten with her and professes his love. His passionate words \nstrike a chord, and they soon become lovers openly.

3.text_:
Though noble, the woman is kind to commoners, sharing both
medicine and money with them as needed. This altruism 
impresses her lover, who finds himself growing ever more 
enamored with her.

4.text_: One day, he finds her in bed with another.\n"You said you loved me!" cries the man.\n"I love everyone equally," she replies.

1.text_:
When Grandpa died, I wanted his pocketwatch to remember 
him by, but my sister took it. Laughing, she said, "All you do is 
sit home and read anyway!" Then she tossed me his tattered 
leather diary instead.

2.text_:
In the diary, I found a record of Grandpa's travels. He was
never the type to stay put, which always caused Grandma no 
end of worry. It's also why I barely have any memories of ever
spending time with him.

3.text_:
"Had a funny dish in a pub the next county over..." "Got 
cleaned out by pickpockets..." The children's books on my
shelves paled in comparison to Grandpa's tales, which had 
an ugliness I greatly desired.

4.text_:
With no watch I know not the time, but I can hear the steam 
whistle outside. I shove the diary into my father's "borrowed" 
travel bag and leave. I know Grandpa would want this, and I 
intend to fill the rest of his pages.

1.text_: In a world where plants no longer grew, a woman became \ninterested in flowers, using what she had to create an artificial \none. And while her creation was pretty, something was lacking.

2.text_: She tried giving it bright colors with spray paint. Neon pink! \nShocking yellow! Laserbolt blue! The colors were quite fun, \nbut something was lacking.

3.text_: Next, she used perfume to give it a scent. Carnal Musk! \nAlabaster Emeralds! Chanterelle No. 4! It smelled lovely, but\nsomething was lacking.

4.text_:
Annoyed, she took her creation and smashed it with a 
hammer. As she stared at it, she began to wonder if this is 
what was meant by "wilting." It was beautiful! Finally, she was
satisfied.

1.text_:
As urban sprawl commenced, nature began to disappear 
from human habitats. Even the forest was not spared, as a 
nearby city planned to clear it and build a large mall, with five 
of its floors forming an atrium-style event hall.

2.text_:
Within the forest was a tall, tall tree with roots longer and 
thicker than any other. It took ten men an entire day to chop it
down. As it fell, red sap gushed and birds circled overhead 
giving call to pained, ominous caws.

3.text_:
The mall opened to much fanfare, but birds still circled 
outside giving their weird cries, and inside there was accident 
after accident. Despite its splendor, customers stopped 
coming and it was soon forced to close.

4.text_:
As the mall fell to ruin, plants reclaimed their home. Though a
 great tree has begun to grow in the atrium, the humans do 
not know this—and a new developer is already planning to
make the site a theme park.

1.text_: The first emperor's staff was a plain stick. The picture of \nsimplicity and fortitude, it served as an embodiment of his \nown honest, sincere ways.

2.text_: The second emperor's staff was an elegant cane. A most\nsplendiferous tool, it reflected his era of blooming culture and \ncivilization.

3.text_: The third emperor's staff was a dazzling treasure. \nThe epitome of luxury, it was decorated from tip to hilt with \ngold leaf and jewels of the most precious variety.

4.text_: But the fourth emperor's staff suffered a dramatic change, \nwhen it was stripped of its jewels, peeled of its gold, and \nsnapped in half by his own people.

1.text_: The girl dreamed of becoming a doctor. She wanted to heal \nher mother's legs, which had grown weak from overwork.

2.text_: Day after day, the girl shunned play so she could diligently \nstudy. But everyone around her poked fun, for they did not\nthink one such as her could become a doctor.

3.text_: But the girl did not give up; she stuck with her studies and \ngave it her all. Eventually, she won over her doubters, and all \nwho knew her came to support her.

4.text_: Centuries later, she finally realized her wish. She exchanged \nthe worn-out parts and healed her mother's legs, and went on \nto be considered the finest android doctor in the land.
