1.text_: It shimmers beautifully beneath the sunlight. Its inky black\ninspires fear in the dark of night. Yet one fickle scholar felt a\nsense of affinity with the sea.

2.text_: The ocean is the cradle of life, yet holds many mysteries.\nIf I could but carve out a portion of the sea, thought the\nscholar, I could get closer to learning its true nature.

3.text_: But of course, putting seawater in a container left the scholar with\nnothing but salt water in a jar, which caused his mind to reel.\n<i>What is the secret!? What makes the ocean what it is!?<i>

4.text_: It was a mystery—the cradle of all life. Yet this mystery was not\ntwo-sided, but spherical. And thinking of how the ocean covers\nthe globe, the scholar began a frantic study of the planets.

1.text_:
I am a fortune teller with many customers. One was hounded by
debt collectors, while another could not accept her husband's
death. I listen to their woes and give them hope, as well as
salvation.

2.text_: A soldier visited today and said he was being sent to the front.\nHe then begged me to scry his future and tell him if he would\never see his beloved wife and infant son again.

3.text_: I gazed into a stone and began my prediction. It was a vague\nexplanation that could apply to anyone, but I ended it by handing\nthe soldier a good luck charm and telling him he was safe.

4.text_: My country tasked me with giving hope to warriors as they face\ndown death, and the man today was but another corpse for the\npile. Alas, in the end, I'm but a criminal in a fortune-teller's skin.

1.text_: The soldier was provided with a single staff that could heal wounds\nwith light, so he healed his injured squadmates on the battlefield as\nblood dripped from his own lips.

2.text_: The soldier was ordered to provide rear support. He expressed his\ndesire to fight at the front with a sword, but no one listened. And as\nhe wielded his staff, blood seeped from his fists.

3.text_: The soldier prayed for revenge. He wanted to attack the man who\nabandoned him and his mother, but had only a healing staff. So he\nprayed the man would not bleed until he a chance to end him.

4.text_: When the injured man came to him, the soldier healed him, then\nbrought the staff down on his head. He healed him again. Smashed\nhim again. Heal. Smash. Heal smash heal smash heal smash heal

1.text_: Strange words fill a rigid body. It looses both his loneliness \nand the thread that binds him.

2.text_: A warm melody echoes through a cold room. The flickering \nlamp illuminates the thread that winds around him.

3.text_: A definite will resounds within a suppressed castle. One the \nthread is severed, two hearts come to life.

4.text_: A pair of footsteps melt into a silent world. Finally free of their \nstrings, this night is the beginning of everything for the pair of \npuppets.

1.text_: One day, three brothers in the same army were sent to fight a \nbattle against terrible odds. Some time later, the youngest \nreturned and told their commander a tale.

2.text_:
On the way to battle, the brothers encountered a merchant. 
He felt pity for trio, and offered each of them a pistol. 
The cautious elder brother chose one with an attached scope, 
while the brawny middle brother took a large-caliber weapon.

3.text_: Unable to speak up for himself, the timid younger brother was\nleft with a completely unremarkable pistol. With their new \nweapons in hand, they made their way to the battle.

4.text_: It turned out that the plain pistol was, in fact, a magical \nweapon that never ran out of ammunition, which is how the \nyoungest brother ended up being the only survivor.

1.text_:
In the long, long ago, a great fire consumed a mountain that 
was home to a unicorn. The poor creature had a child in her 
belly, and as the flames leapt around her, she prayed that the
child might somehow be saved.

2.text_:
The unicorn was born as the mother burned to death—but her
prayer had been heard, and the foal was granted an odd 
physicality that made him resistant to fire. Legs shaking, the 
foal stood and watched as the fire consumed everything.

3.text_:
The foal was now alone on the desolate scorched mountain, 
and it cried by its mother's side for three days and nights. 
On the fourth day, a small green bud sprouted, and the foal 
immediately began to love it as if it were his own mother.

4.text_:
A thousand years passed. The bud grew and grew, eventually 
becoming the sacred tree of the mountain, while the foal slept 
beneath its branches, protecting both the tree and all that 
lived within it from the ravages of fire.

1.text_: In a town of incessant rain, a woman lost her child in a flood. \nFrom that day forth, she would stare through the rain at the \nraging river beyond, hoping to find her child.

2.text_:
One day, an abandoned baby washed up on the riverbank. 
Feeling certain the baby was her child reborn, she decided to 
raise it with love. Afterward, whenever floods washed through 
the town, the woman's house alone was spared.

3.text_:
The other villages began to view the child as cursed, and 
grew resentful when floodwaters ravaged their town. 
Eventually, the woman and her child were blamed outright 
and sentenced to die.

4.text_:
On the eve of their execution, the woman instead did the 
deed herself with a pistol, after which the floods ceased. 
Indeed, nary a drop of rain ever fell in the town again, and it 
eventually dried up and blew away in the dust.

1.text_:
Legends tell of a time long, long ago when the god of light 
created six weapons and scattered them across the world. 
One such weapon, a beautiful pistol, was handed down 
through the generations in a country filled with heathens.

2.text_: The heathens' most important laws were "Do not fight" and \n"Do not kill." So while the pistol had been handed down as a \nprecious treasure, it was never used as a weapon.

3.text_:
One day, the king of another nation invaded so that he might 
claim the pistol for his own. The heathens refused to fight, and
 were slaughtered to a man. But when the carnage was over, 
the invaders could not locate the pistol.

4.text_:
Years passed, and the country of heathens was abandoned. 
One day, a pure and innocent child wandered into the ruins 
and found a beautiful pistol. For the god of light had created 
a weapon invisible to any who had taken a life.

1.text_: To forget the way in a blur of scenery  \nThe lone figure a wisp of smoke in the gap between moments

2.text_: To forget illness in a hazy memory  \nThe mere trace clouded by somber hues

3.text_: To forget wakefulness in sinking consciousness  \nThe fear of nothingness grows ever muddled

4.text_: To forget a life of misery in blinding decadence  \nThe grasping arms fade into oblivion

1.text_: Taking the life of another is the most forbidden of acts.

2.text_: But there are moments where such an act is needed. In such \ntimes, tools known as "guns" can easily settle the matter.

3.text_: Load the bullet. Cock the hammer. Aim. Pull the trigger. It is \nsimplicity itself.

4.text_: The freed bullet will pierce your skull in an instant, sending \nyou to the afterlife without a hint of pain. Delightful, is it not?

1.text_: Kid lost his parents that day. Laid low by debt collectors, they \nwere. Don't reckon he had anyone else to turn to, so he tried \nto make what kind of life he could in this broken-down town.

2.text_: Kid found the gun that day. Think he was rooting around for \nmetal to sell out at the old ruined factory. Pretty impressive \nfind—guns ain't easy to get your hands on in this town.

3.text_: Kid was attacked that day. I saw the debt collectors force their \nway into his home, and... Well, I ain't proud, but I ran. Not like\nI wanted to be their next target, you know?

4.text_: I killed for the first time that day. I shot and killed the men who\n came to my house. And if it is true that the strong devour the \nweak, then I will use this gun to become strong.

1.text_:
I wander aimlessly beneath the scorching noonday sun. How 
cruel to be given a mission in a place like this! But this was an
important task—one for me alone— which meant I had no 
one to complain to.

2.text_:
My mission is to eliminate a certain family. It's not their fault—
not really, anyway. They just stumbled across some classified 
information. Yet the commands of heaven know not goodness
or malice, and a die once cast cannot be changed.

3.text_:
I continue to walk under a blazing sun. As I gaze at the 
mirages that boil up from the earth, reality begins to slip from
my grasp. But my destination is near, so I keep myself 
grounded, my feet firmly planted on the earth.

4.text_:
When I reach my destination, I find the house is smaller than 
I remember. Inside are withered, desiccated corpses. Corpses 
I had shot. Corpses of my beloved wife and child. Slowly, 
I turn my back on reality and shut the door again.

1.text_: Folks, are you tired of titan-related problems cropping up in \nyour life? Of course you are! Why, there's a whole land of the \ndevils not a stone's throw from here!

2.text_: A single titan sneeze can cause a violent storm that sends \nfolks like us toppling ass over teakettle. Why, there have even \nbeen people whose entire homes were blown away!

3.text_: Now I don't want to get crude here, folks. But some titans are \nbig as mountains, and when nature calls... Well, lets just say \nthat's one flood you do NOT want to be caught in!

4.text_: But I've got great news: This here wonder product snuffs out\npesky titans with a single pull of a trigger! Buy now, and we'll even\npay shipping and handling. Don't let it pass you by! Order today!

1.text_: The train in which I ride will soon enter a tunnel. It's cursed, \napparently—or so I've been told.

2.text_: The tunnel is built on an old battleground where lots of people \ndied, and their ghosts are said to snatch the living from the \ntrain while it's inside the tunnel.

3.text_: The train enters the tunnel. The whistle shrieks. I feel a brief \ntickle run down my spine as I consider the possibility a ghost \nmight take me.

4.text_: On the other side of the tunnel is a dense forest— my final \ndestination. I am going there to die, so what, exactly, am I \nafraid of?

1.text_: Once, a special ore was found in an underground mine. \nWhen a scientist discovered the ore held a strange magic, he\ndecided to construct a gun that used it for bullets.

2.text_:
This is the age of scientific advancement! people cried as 
they mocked him. "Are you really going to shoot rocks!?" 
But the scientist did not give up, and before long his weapon 
was complete.

3.text_:
The first use of the gun proved its remarkable power:
A single bullet was fired in front of an audience of jeering 
onlookers, and pierced not only the target, but the wall behind
it as well.

4.text_: The scientist was instantly showered with praise, and the \nweapon put on display in a museum. Alas, it would never \nshow off its might again.

1.text_: How large was the gun! All who saw it cried in admiration.

2.text_: How sturdy was the gun! All who touched it sobbed in delight.

3.text_: How powerful was the gun! All who received it howled in \necstasy.

4.text_: The man with the gun contributed greatly to the perpetuation \nof his underwater people—and it is not hard to imagine what\nhis remains turned out to be.

1.text_:
December. The fort is strangely cold, so soldiers huddle 
together and drink. It is the season where talk grows lively as 
they speak of loved ones left behind, and the young man is 
no exception.

2.text_:
The young man has no lover, but as the others talk, he 
remembers the girl he broke up with before setting off to war. 
He did so because he would be gone a long time and was 
not certain to return.

3.text_:
Did she now look over the same white drifts of snow back 
home? The young man felt his proximity to death made her 
off-limits, yet his companions claimed their lovers were the 
reason they fought.

4.text_:
It snowed lightly the following morning, turning the ground to 
mud—but the troops marched off to battle like always. As he 
trudged, the young man swore to see his love again if he 
survived.

1.text_:
There was once a smith in a country beset by war. Even 
though he felt shame in supporting his wife and daughter by 
making killing tools, he worked tirelessly to craft his potent 
weapons.

2.text_:
Soon, the royal army began using his guns, which they 
considered superior to all others. The smith, relieved to have
income, swore to buy his wife and daughter whatever they 
liked.

3.text_:
But his wife and daughter felt too much guilt over his 
weapons to accept the fruits of their profit, so the smith 
arranged an audience with the king and asked the army to 
stop using his weapons.

4.text_:
The king agreed, then ordered his soldiers to kill the smith. 
But in keeping to his wish, his guns were never used in battle 
again—instead, they were used to execute enemies of the 
state.

1.text_:
An evil man who committed a heinous crime was sentenced 
to die in accordance with the law. But his would be a special 
method of execution, and so the week before, he was placed 
in a jail cell and given a gun.

2.text_:
The man waited for his day to come. Though he had accepted 
the weight of his crime and the reality of his execution, he still
found himself tormented by the thought of death. And when 
the week passed, he was still alive.

3.text_: Though relieved, the man was haunted by the anxiety of not \nknowing when his execution would be carried out. And as \nanother month passed, he was still alive.

4.text_:
The moment he reached his limit, he understood the meaning 
behind the gun and shot himself on the spot. This was the 
preferred death-penalty method, for it caused the least 
distress to the actual executioners.

1.text_:
There was once a vile military unit called the Red Devils.
They were a terrifying bunch, made up of the most heinous
criminals in the world. They fought for bloodlust alone;
a band of mindless, carnage-soaked instruments.

2.text_:
One member of the force was a female gunslinger who was 
the very picture of cruelty. The more she pulled the trigger, the
more enemies died. This clarity suited her, which is why she 
wielded a gun.

3.text_: Load. Aim. Fire. Load. Aim. Fire. Load. Aim. Fire.\nShe did not just use a gun—she was a gun.

4.text_:
She once claimed she had no right to call herself
human; rather, she was a heartless tool for having
betrayed love. For no matter how much death her
gun dealt out, it remained as cold as ice.

1.text_: Blackbirds caw over an eerie alleyway where an old woman \nis selling a gun. Her customer, a man, asks what sort of \nweapon it is.

2.text_: The woman grins and informs him of the gun's peculiar trait: \nIt will only fire a bullet if the one you turn it on wishes you \ndead. The man finds this fascinating, and buys it on the spot.

3.text_:
That night, the man covertly turns the gun on each member 
of his family. And while no bullets are fired, he finds himself 
plagued by remorse for having doubted his family, and sets 
the gun aside.

4.text_: But then he hears his son cry out. "Whoa, Dad! This gun is \nAWESOME!" Thus did the man meet his end, for the boy had \nalways been such a little jerk...

1.text_:
An empire's culture once spread and flourished during a long 
period of peace. Pottery decorated with dazzling paintings 
fetched large sums of money, and were collected by the 
art-loving emperor.

2.text_: In a remote village, a girl was born with great skill in painting. \nShe came to the capital to learn the potter's ways, and her \nfirst piece caught the eye of an official who invited her to court.

3.text_: The emperor admired both the girl's skill and her beauty, and \nwanted her as his consort. She accepted on the condition she \ncould paint whenever she liked.

4.text_:
But the other consorts were jealous of the girl, and one night 
they cut off her arm. Despondent at no longer being able to 
hold a brush, she took a gun from the emperor's collection 
and shot herself.

1.text_:
Ever since his father's death, the boy had searched for his 
murderer. He traveled with his father's gun in his hand as he 
collected information on his target. Though it was grueling, he 
knew he was getting closer.

2.text_:
He dreamed of the murder every night. A burglar had forced 
his way into their home, and though the boy bravely placed 
himself in harm's way, the burglar paid him no mind and shot 
his father down.

3.text_:
As he traveled, he learned of his father's secret side. Many 
cursed him, and some drew iron at the very mention of his 
name. But the boy carried on, for he did not want to believe 
his father's smiles had been false.

4.text_:
Years later, he found his target's home, went inside, and 
pointed his gun. Just then, the man's daughter ran between 
them. He hesitated, at which point he was laid low by the 
same gun that killed his father.

1.text_: Hey there, pal! First time here, yeah? C'mere, sit down, \nlemme buy you a drink. All my buddies left, so you and me \nmight as well drink together, right!?

2.text_:
Dunno about you, but alcohol's a scary thing. Those buddies 
of mine I told you about? Once they get loaded, they start 
whining like crazy. "My feelings! Listen to my feelings!" Blah, 
blah, blah. Know what I mean, pal?

3.text_: Not to brag, but I got a special talent for reading people's \nminds. So I looked at my buddies and said, "Why don't I \nguess what you're all thinking?"

4.text_: Ha ha! You shoulda seen 'em when I nailed every last detail! \n...How's that, pal? You wanna see me talent in action? Hey, \nno problem! You're my new drinking buddy, after all!

1.text_: There are words we mustn't say in this world, and it's my job \nto stamp them out. I'm proud of what I do; I believe my efforts \nmake the world a more proper place.

2.text_:
Today I came across some townspeople causing a ruckus. 
They started cursing the moment they saw me, but my bullets 
drowned them out. Yes sir, my honest work is making the 
world a cleaner place.

3.text_:
Today I went to the house of someone who had once picked a 
fight with me. He started yelling when I entered, so I knew my 
bad feeling was right. No, my good feeling. Because my bullet 
rids the world of distortion.

4.text_:
Today I shot my homeroom teacher. Why do adults always, 
always, say such dirty words to me? Calling me worthless, 
dumb, trash... It's unforgiveable. A world that won't 
acknowledge me is just wrong, and that's a fact.

1.text_:
"I wish the captain would get it together."
"Maybe he hates being called a coward."
"He retreated so damn fast last time!"
"We're alive. Ain't that enough?"

2.text_:
"He's usually so quiet, you know?"
"Right? Guy only perks up during battle."
"Like how he worried about that kid."
"Yeah, I hear rumors about his past..."

3.text_:
"Guess he was a hot-shot back in the day."
"Still, you can't fake his recent success."
"You think retreats are a strategy?"
"I think he looks out for us."

4.text_:
"Leave him behind and retreat!?"
"Yep. Direct orders from the captain."
"Screw that! I'm goin' back in there!"
"Sounds like we're on the same page."

1.text_: There was once a clockwork soldier built for war. His king \ndesired to build a powerful army to make his country rich, so \nthe soldier was given a gun and ordered to see his wish done.

2.text_:
He fought in accordance with his king's orders. His aim never 
missed, and his bullets pierced enemy armor with ease. 
He gave no thought to himself, concerned only with the will of 
his ruler.

3.text_: Other clockwork soldiers fought with him, and they quickly \nannihilated the enemy. He then sat alone, looking at his gun \nand thinking of the king's will which was so near completion.

4.text_:
But then the king ordered him to shoot himself, for the data 
determined he was an inferior model. Dismantled and 
discarded as scrap, he became the foundation for the king's 
desires.

1.text_:
The man traveled to many battles.
 
He distinguished himself in all of them, and achieved great fame
and glory.

2.text_:
The man took many lives.
 
He mercilessly shot down any who defied him as he snuffed out
enemy after enemy.

3.text_:
The man saved many lives.
 
He killed the enemies who endangered his homeland, thus saving
all who inhabited it.

4.text_: After his death, a medal of honor was created in his name,\nand any who earn it win both great glory and a model of the man's\nfavorite gun.
After his death, a medal of honor was created in his name,\nand any who earn it win both great glory and a model of the man's\nfavorite gun.

1.text_:
There was once a man with a strong sense of justice. 
He wanted nothing more than to save as many lives as he 
could, so he set out to find a profession that would let him 
live out his dream.

2.text_: As time passed, he did, in fact, save many lives—and his \nhandmade gun was used only to protect others, never to \nrecklessly kill in anger.

3.text_: Several years later, he fell to the assassin's bullet. In honor of\n all the good he'd done, his favorite gun was cleaned and \ncarefully stored as a memento.

4.text_: Many years later, the true quality of the gun became known, \nand the military immediately began mass-producing it as a \nweapon of war, where it went on to take many noble lives.

1.text_: This thing here? Notorious with the gangs. Heard they used \nto use it for a little life-risking gamble. \nYep, that's right: the ol' Russian roulette.

2.text_:
Long time ago, there were two groups of villains what ran this
whole area. Neither one could gain an advantage, so the 
bosses finally decided to settle things between 'em once and 
for all.

3.text_: They used this gun here to do it, but there's a catch: neither \none of 'em died. No bullets came out, see? And lemme just \nsay, there's no trickery at work here.

4.text_: Anyway, the bosses forged an alliance, built this nation, and \nmade this gun a symbol of peace. I think true villains attract \nfates that lead to their survival, no matter how the bullets fall.

1.text_: There was once a wealthy man who liked to collect guns. \nOne of his particular favorites was a gorgeous weapon \ncovered in all manner of delicate decorations.

2.text_: In addition to being lovely, the gun was exceedingly powerful, \nand enthusiasts everywhere considered it a shining example \nof the craft—which only caused its value to rise.

3.text_: One night, a robber snuck into the mansion to steal the gun. \nBut he ran into the man, and each quickly drew their weapon \non the other.

4.text_: In that moment, the robber emerged superior—for the wealthy\n man, not wanting the pistol to be dirtied by discharge, had \nbeen unable to pull the trigger.

1.text_:
Once, a man was drafted into a war between two great 
countries. The experience traumatized him, and he spent his 
days in distress over the possibility of being attacked at any 
moment.

2.text_:
But a chance meeting with a beautiful woman prompted him 
to change. He wished to live a life of ease and build a happy 
family with her, so he slowly battled his trauma while keeping 
it secret.

3.text_: Their relationship progressed smoothly, and a year after he \nmet her, he decided to propose. But just as he was about to \npull the ring from his breast pocket, a bullet pierced his body.

4.text_: The woman lowered her gun and began to sob. It turns out \nshe, too, had been traumatized by war, and when the man \nreached for the ring, she thought he was going for a weapon.

1.text_: RATIO DECIDENDI\nThe facts of the crime:\n(a) The defendant obtained a handgun through gambling.

2.text_:
(b) The defendant took the gun home, but had reservations 
about attempting suicide. When his father tried to stop him, 
they fought. During the scuffle, the defendant fired the 
weapon, killing his father instantly.

3.text_: (c) The defendant became despondent and took the gun to a \ndowntown area, where the gun was fired indiscriminately into \na shopping district, killing or wounding sixteen.

4.text_: JUDGMENT\nDefendant shall be executed.\nThe confiscated gun shall be impounded.

1.text_:
It was an odd gun, and not just in appearance. It had 
unlimited ammo, but the weight needed to pull the trigger 
matched that of who it was pointed at, which made using it a 
tricky business.

2.text_: One woman, for example, met a horrible end when she \nlacked the strength to pull the trigger on her mortal enemy \nand was killed in return.

3.text_: Another man turned the gun on his frail, bedridden mother—\nbut when he noticed how much lighter the trigger was than he \nwas expecting, he broke down in tears.

4.text_:
A final man used it on birds, mice, and unwanted children. 
And over the course of taking so many lives, the gun came to 
forget the weight of a life, and the trigger became light as a 
feather.

1.text_: From where are we born? To where do we go?\nThere is no way to know, for a life enters this world with no\nrecollection of what transpired even a moment before.

2.text_: A life brought into this world vanishes without taking form, ever\nunaware of who they are or what feelings they have gained.

3.text_: A freed life inherits the feelings of her older sister. But once\nshe fulfills this wish, where will she go next?

4.text_: From where are we born? To where do we go?\nThere is no need to ask such questions, because it is impossible\nto know what tomorrow holds.

1.text_: The man was a gunsmith. Even after the war ended and he left\nthe army, he continues to craft his beloved weapons, despite\nthem being useless in this new and peaceful age.

2.text_: The man's dream was to craft a gun of such elegant beauty that\nit enraptured all who saw it. And after years of trial and error, he\nforged a weapon so beautiful that he fell in love with it.

3.text_: As though possessed by a demon, he used his new love to kill\none innocent person after the next. As he did so, he muttered\nabout needing bodies equally as beautiful as his weapon.

4.text_: The man was eventually sentenced to death for his actions. But\nthe gun was acknowledged as an artistic masterwork, and is still\nfired once a year to mark the anniversary of the war's end.

1.text_: Two countries were attempting to merge, but could not agree how\nto share power. To break the stalemate, each sent a knight to a\nfight to the death where the winner would determine who ruled.

2.text_: The knights did not exchange greetings, but instead set upon\neach other. For three days and nights they fought, until finally both\nfell to their knees and praised the other.

3.text_:
The knights rose and gleefully declared war against their two
countries. The countries joined forces against this new and
terrible threat, but found themselves being overwhelmed by
the knights' might.

4.text_: The two knights lay smiling on the ground, their bodies ravaged\nby sword and spear, axe and arrow. And having worked together\nto fell a great foe, the two countries decided to finally become one.

1.text_: I've recently come to think of myself as a terrible man who\nneglected his family for years in order to pursue his own selfish\nadventures.

2.text_: I never used to know homesickness. But these days, images of my\nfamily surface in my mind whenever I travel. And now that I miss\nthem, my skills are starting to slip.

3.text_: I've caused my wife and my daughter nothing but trouble. I know\nthis—I've known it the entire time. But my inarticulate nature and\nstubborn pride always got in the way of change.

4.text_: Next time I go home, I'll muster up my courage and tell them what\nI feel. I'll tell them I'm sorry for causing so much pain over the\nyears. Yes, the next time I go home, I will...

1.text_:
Mommy and Daddy.
Daddy works all the time.
Mommy is angry all the time.
Why?

2.text_:
My friends.
I thought we'd be friends forever.
But I guess you were different.
Why?

3.text_:
Me.
No one pays attention to me.
No one sees who I really am.
Why?

4.text_:
You.
You pay attention to me.
You see who I really am.
Thank you.
